div.p: As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE.

q.l: In amore haec omnia inſunt vitia; injuriae,

div.p: LONDON: Printed for P. VAILLANT, facing Southampton-Street in the Strand. MDCCLXI.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE firſt hint of this Comedy was ſuggeſted by the Cocu Imaginaire of Moliere, who took the idea of his piece from an Italian writer. Though jealouſy, in all its appearances, has been frequently exhibited on the Engliſh ſtage, yet it was imagined that a plan, which ſhould delineate all the varieties of that paſſion, whether ſubſiſting between lovers or in the matrimonial life, and blend them together in one piece, would not be unacceptable to the public. If therefore there is atonement made for the want of originality of character by the decency of the dialogue, the novelty of the fable, and the complication of the incidents, the author has compaſſed all that he propoſed to himſelf in the enſuing ſcenes; which, with pleaſure he finds, were the occaſion of producing the too long concealed powers of Miſs Haughton, and of ſhewing, in a diſtinguiſhed light, the exquiſite acting of Mr. Obrien.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Sir JOHN RESTLESS and ROBERT, from a Houſe in the Side Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: SIR John Reſtleſs!—Sir John Reſtleſs! thou haſt play'd the fool with a vengeance.—What devil whiſpered thee to marry ſuch a woman?—Robert,—you have been a faithful ſervant in my family, Robert, and I value you.—Did your lady go out at this door here into the park, or did ſhe go out at the ſtreet door?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: This door, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, I will never live in a houſe again that has two doors to it.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will give warning to my landlord inſtantly.—The eyes of Argus are not ſufficient to watch the motions of a wife, where there is a ſtreet door, and a back door, to favour her eſcapes.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I wiſh—you will pardon my boldneſs, Sir,—I wiſh you would ſhake off this uneaſineſs that preys upon your ſpirits—It grieves me to the heart,—it does, indeed, Sir, to ſee you in this way—Baniſh your ſuſpicions, Sir—you have conceived ſome ſtrange averſion, I am afraid, to my lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Robert; no averſion—in ſpite of me I doat upon her ſtill—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Then why will you not think generouſly, Sir, of the perſon you love?—my lady, I dare be ſworn—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Is falſe to me.—That embitters my whole life—I love her, and ſhe repays me with ingratitude, with perfidy,—with falſehood,—with—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I dare be ſworn, Sir, ſhe is a woman of honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, I have conſidered you as a friend in my houſe—Don't you betray me too—Don't juſtify her—don't—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Dear Sir, if you will but give me leave—you have been an indulgent maſter to me, and I am only concerned for your welfare—You married my lady for love, and I have heard you ſo warm in her praiſe—why will you go back from thoſe ſentiments?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, I married her for love—Oh! love! love!—What miſchief doſt thou not occaſion in this world?—Yes, Robert; I married her for love.—When firſt I ſaw her I was not ſo much ſtruck with her beauty, as with that air of an ingenuous mind that appeared in her countenance;—her features did not ſo much charm me with their ſymmetry, as that expreſſion of ſweetneſs, that ſmile that indicated affability, modeſty, and compliance.—But, honeſt Robert, I was deceived—I was not a month married, when I ſaw her practiſing thoſe very ſmiles at her glaſs—I ſaw thro' the artifice; plainly ſaw there was nothing natural in her manner, but all forced, all ſtudied, put on with her head-dreſs—I was alarmed; I reſolved to watch her from that moment, and I have ſeen ſuch things—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I believe you wrong her, and wrong yourſelf—you build on groundleſs ſurmizes;—you make yourſelf unhappy, and my lady too; and by being conſtantly uneaſy, and never ſhewing her the leaſt love,—you'll forgive me, Sir,—you ſill her mind with ſtrange ſuſpicions, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Suſpicions, Robert!

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; ſtrange ſuſpicions!—My lady finds herſelf treated with no degree of tenderneſs; ſhe infers that, your inclinations are fixed elſewhere, and ſo ſhe is become—you will pardon my blunt honeſty—ſhe is become downright jealous,—as jealous as yourſelf, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! Robert, you are little read in the arts of women; you little know the intricacies of their conduct; the mazes thro' which they walk, ſhifting, turning, winding, running into devious paths, but tending all thro' a labyrinth
to the temple of Venus;—you cannot ſee, Robert, that all her pretences to ſuſpect me of infidelity are merely a counter-plot to cover her own looſe deſigns;—'tis but a gauze-covering, tho'—it is ſeen thro' and only ſerves to ſhew her guilt the more.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir John, I cannot ſee—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Robert; I know you can't—her ſuſpicions of me all make againſt her; they are but female ſtratagems, and yet it is but too true that ſhe ſtill is near my heart.—Oh! Robert, Robert, when I have watched her at a play, or elſewhere,—when I have counted her oglings, and her whiſperings, her ſtolen glances, and her artful leer, with the cunning of her ſex, ſhe has pretended to be as watchful of me—Diſſembling, falſe, deceitful woman!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: And yet, I dare aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No more; I am not to be deceived; I know her thoroughly, and now,—now—has not ſhe eſcaped out of my houſe, even now?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: But with no bad deſign.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I am the beſt judge of that—which way did ſhe go?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Acroſs the Park, Sir—that way, Sir—towards the Horſe-guards—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Towards the Horſe-guards!—there,—there,—there—the thing is evident;—you may go in, Robert.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Go in, I ſay; go in—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: There is no perſuading him to his own good

Gone towards the Horſe-guards!—my head aches,—my forehead burns—I am cutting my
horns—Gone towards the Horſe-Guards!—I'll purſue her thither; if I find her, her uſual artifice will fail her—the time, the place, will all inform againſt her.—Sir John! Sir John! you were a madman to marry ſuch a woman.—

div.stage: Enter BEVERLEY and BELLMONT, at oppoſite Sides.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ha! my dear Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Beverley!—I rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! I ſuppoſe the ſame cauſe has brought us both into the Park; both come to ſigh amorous vows in the friendly gloom of yonder walk;—Belinda keeps a perpetual war of love and grief, and hope and fear in my heart—and let me ſee— (lays his hand on Bellmont's breaſt) how fares all here? I fancy my ſiſter is a little buſy here—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Buſy!—ſhe makes a perfect riot there—not one wink the whole night—Oh! Clariſſa, Clariſſa! her form ſo animated! her eyes ſo—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee! truce; I have not leiſure to attend to her praiſe—a ſiſter's praiſe too!—Faith, the greateſt merit I ever could ſee in Clariſſa is, that ſhe loves you freely and ſincerely.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: And to be even with you, Sir,—your Belinda, upon my ſoul, notwithſtanding all your laviſh praiſes, her higheſt perfection, in my mind, is her ſenſibility to the merit of my friend.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Oh! Bellmont, don't talk prophanely—Such a girl!
Scarce can I to heav'n excuſe
The devotion which I uſe
Unto that adored dame;
But, my dear Bellmont, tell me honeſtly now, do you think ſhe has ever betrayed the leaſt regard for me?—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: How can you, Beverley, you that have ſuch convincing proofs, how can you aſk ſuch a queſtion—that uneaſineſs of yours, that inquietude of mind—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee now don't fix that character upon me—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: It is your character, my dear Beverley: and inſtead of enjoying the object before you, you are ever looking back to ſomething paſt, or conjecturing about ſomething to come, and are your own ſelf-tormentor.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, no, no; don't ſay ſo; I hate the very notion of ſuch a temper: the thing is, when a man loves tenderly as I do, ſollicitude and anxiety are natural; and when Belinda's father oppoſes my warmeſt wiſhes—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Why yes, the good Mr. Blandford is willing to give her in marriage to me.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The ſenſeleſs old dotard!—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Thank you for the compliment!—and my father, the wiſe Sir William Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Is a tyrannical, poſitive, headſtrong—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: There again I thank you—But in ſhort, the old couple, Belinda's father and mine, have both agreed upon the match, and they inſiſt upon compliance from their children; ſo that, according to them, I am to be married off-hand to your miſtreſs, and you and your ſiſter, poor Clariſſa, are to be left to ſhift for yourſelves.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Racks and torment!—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
Racks and torment!—Seas of milk and ſhips of amber, man!—we are ſailing to our
wiſhed for harbour, in ſpite of their machinations.—I have ſettled the whole affair with Clariſſa.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: I have, and to-morrow morning makes me poſſeſſor of her charms.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My dear boy, give us your hand;—and then, thou dear rogue, and then Belinda's mine— (ſings) Loll-toll-loll—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Well may you be in raptures, Sir; for here, here, here they both come—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Grace was in all her ſteps; heav'n in her eye;
In every geſture, dignity and love.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: A poetical reception truly!—But can't your paſſion inſpire you to a compoſition of your own Mr. Beverley?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It inſpires me with ſentiments, Madam, which I can't find words to expreſs.—Sucklin, Waller, Landſdown, and all our dealers in loveverſes, give but a faint image of a heart touched like mine.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman! what a terrible taking you are in! But if the ſonneteers cannot give an image of you, Sir, have you had recourſe to a painter, as you promiſed me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have Belinda, and here,—here is the humble portrait of your adorer.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well! there is a likeneſs—but after all, there is a better painter than this gentleman, whoever he be.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A better!—now ſhe is diſcontented (aſide) where, Madam, can a better be found?—if money can purchaſe him—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, when he draws for money he never ſucceeds—But when pure inclination prompts him, then his colouring is warm indeed—He gives a portrait that endears the original.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Such an artiſt is worth the Indies.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You need not go ſo far to ſeek him—he has done your buſineſs already—The limner I mean is a certain little blind god, called Love, and he has ſtamped ſuch an impreſſion of you here—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt obedient,—and I can tell you, that the very ſame gentleman has been at work for you too.—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: (who had been talking apart with Clariſſa.) Oh! he has had a world of buſineſs upon his hands, for we two have been agreeing what havock he has made with us.

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Yes, but we are but in a kind of fool's paradiſe here; all our ſchemes are but mere caſtle-building, which your father, Mr. Bellmont,—and my dear Belinda,—yours too are moſt obſtinately determined to deſtroy.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Why as you ſay, they are determined that I ſhall have the honour of Belinda's hand in the country-dance of matrimony.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Without conſidering that I may like another partner better—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And without conſidering that I, forlorn as I am, and my ſiſter, there—who is as well inclined to a matrimonial game of romps as any girl in Chriſtendom, muſt both of us ſit down, and lead apes in hell, in ſpite of our ſtrongeſt inclinations to mingle in the groupe.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
But we have planned our own happineſs, and with a little reſolution we ſhall be ſucceſsful
in the end I warrant ye.—Clariſſa, my angel, let us take a turn this way, and leave that love-ſick pair to themſelves—they are only fit company for each other, and we can find wherewithal to entertain ourſelves.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Ay! let us turn this way.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What are you going to leave us, Clariſſa?—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Only juſt ſauntering into this ſidewalk—we ſha'nt loſe one another.—

sp.speaker: BELIND.
sp.p: Oh! you are ſuch a tender couple—you are not tired I ſee of ſaying pretty ſoft things to each other.—Well! well!—take your own way.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: And if I gueſs right, you are glad to be left together—Belinda.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who I?—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: You, my dear—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Not I truly—let us walk together.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: No, no, by no means—you ſhall be indulged—adieu!—we ſhall be within call.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My ſiſter is frankly in love with Bellmont—I wiſh Belinda would act as openly towards me—I wiſh ſhe has not a lurking inclination for Bellmont. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir!—Thoughtful!—Oh! I'll call Mr. Bellmont back, if that is the caſe.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She will call Mr. Bellmont back. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir; am I to entertain you, or you me?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Madam!—ha! ha! why you look as
if you were frightened—are you afraid of being left alone with me?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Belinda, you know that is the happineſs of my life;—but—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But what, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am afraid I have done ſomething to offend you.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To offend me!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, Belinda; I ſhould have been of the party laſt night; I own I ſhould; it was a ſufficient inducement for me that you was to be there; it was my fault, and you I ſee are piqued at it.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I piqued!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſee you are; and you was ſo laſt night too—I have heard it all, and in mere reſentment you directed all your diſcourſe to Mr. Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If I did, it was merely accidental.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, it was deliberately done;—forgive my raſh folly in refuſing the invitation—I meant no manner of harm—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who imagines you did, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Belinda, you take offence too lightly—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! what have you taken into your head now?—this uneaſineſs is of your own making—I have taken nothing ill, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You could not but take it ill; but by all that's amiable about you, I meant not to incur your diſpleaſure—forgive that abrupt anſwer I ſent—I ſhould have made a handſomer apology.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Apology!—what occaſion was there for any thing more?—you ſaid you was pre-engaged, did not you?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſaid ſo; I own it, and beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Beg my pardon! for what? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I only meant—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! can you think I ſee any thing in your meſſage to be offended at, Sir?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Where you were concerned, I own I ſhould have expreſſed myſelf with more delicacy, than thoſe haſty words, I am engaged, and can't wait upon you to-night. I ſhould have told you that my heart was with you, though neceſſity dragged me another way—but this omiſſion you reſented—I could learn, ſince, the ſpirits you were in the whole evening, though I enjoyed nothing in your abſence—I could hear the ſallies of your wit, the ſprightlineſs of your converſation, and on whom your eyes were fixed the whole night.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: They were fixed upon Mr. Bellmont, you think!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ay! and fixed with delight upon him; ſeemed negociating the buſineſs of love before the whole company.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, whoever is your author, he has miſinformed you; and let me tell you, you alarm me with theſe fancies, and you know I have often told you that you are of too refining a temper—you create for yourſelf imaginary miſunderſtandings, and then are ever entering into explanations—I aſſure you, Mr. Beverley, this watching for intelligence, from the ſpies and miſrepreſenters of converſation, betrays the ſymptoms of jealouſy, and I would not be married to a jealous man for the world.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Now ſhe is ſeeking occaſion to break off.— (aſide.) Jealouſy, Ma'am, can never get admiſſion into my breaſt, I am of too generous
a temper; a certain delicacy I own I have; I value the opinion of my friends, and when there are circumſtances of a doubtful aſpect, I am glad to ſet things in their true light;—and ſurely, Belinda, if I do ſo with others, ſurely with you on whom my happineſs depends to deſire a favourable interpretation of my words and actions—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But theſe little humours may grow up, and gather into the fixed diſeaſe of jealouſy at laſt.— (Lady Reſtleſs croſſes the ſtage, and rings a bell at the door.) And there now,—there goes a lady who is a victim to her own fretful imagination—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Who is the lady pray?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My lady Reſtleſs;—walk this way, and I will give you her whole character—I am not acquainted with her ladyſhip, but I have heard much of her—this way—this way—

sp.speaker: Lady RESTLESS
sp.p: What do theſe ſervants mean?—there is ſomething going forward here—I will be let in or I will know the reaſon why— (rings again) but in the mean time, Sir John can let any body he pleaſes out at the ſtreet-door—I'll run up the ſteps here, and obſerve.

div.stage: TATTLE opens the door, MARMALET follows her.

sp.speaker: TATTLE.
sp.p: Who rung this bell?—I don't ſee any body—and yet I am ſure the bell rung.—Well, Mrs. Marmalet, you will be going, I ſee.—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Tattle; I muſt be going; I'll run acroſs the Park, and I ſhall ſoon get to Groſvenor-Square—when ſhall I ſee you at our houſe?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Oh! the Lord knows when I ſhall be able to get out—my lady leads us all ſuch lives—Oh! I wiſh I had ſuch another place as you have of it.—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Heaven be praiſed! I have nothing to complain of.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: No, that you have not: Lord! when ſhall I get ſuch a gown as that you have on by my lady—She will never fling off ſuch a thing, and give it to a poor ſervant.—Worry, worry, worry herſelf, and every body elſe too—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: No; there is nobody ſtirring that way—what do I ſee?—a huſſy coming out of my houſe!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Well, I muſt be gone, Mrs. Tattle—fare you well—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: She is dizoned out too! Madam is! why did not you open the door, Tattle, when I rung?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I came as ſoon as poſſible, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Who have you with you here?—what is your buſineſs, miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My buſineſs, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In confuſion too!—the caſe is plain—you come here after Sir John, I ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I come after Sir John, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Guilt in her face! yes, after Sir John; and Tattle, you are in the plot againſt me; you were favouring her eſcape, were you?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I favour her eſcape, madam!—there is no occaſion for that.—This is Mrs. Marmalet, madam, an acquaintance of mine, madam, that is come to ſee me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! very fine, miſtreſs! you bring your creatures after the vile man, do you?—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I aſſure you, madam, I am a very honeſt girl—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! I dare ſay ſo—where did you get that gown?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: La! ma'am!—I came by it honeſtly—my lady Conqueſt gave it to me—I live with my lady Conqueſt, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a complexion ſhe has!—how long have you lived in London?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Three years, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In London three years with that complexion! it can't be—but perhaps ſhe is painted—all theſe creatures paint—you are all ſo many painted dolls (rubs her face with a white handkerchief) no—it does not come off—ſo, Mrs. Tattle, you bring your freſh country girls here to my houſe, do you?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Upon my credit, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't tell me—I ſee thro' this affair—Go you about your buſineſs, miſtreſs, and let me never ſee you about my doors again—go—go—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Lord, ma'am, I ſhan't trouble your houſe—Mrs. Tattle, a good day—here's a deal to do, indeed—I have as good a houſe as her's to go to—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
There, there, there;—ſee there;—ſhe goes off in a huff! the way with them all—ay! I ſee how it is, Tattle,—you falſe, ungrateful—that
gown was never given her by a woman—ſhe had that from Sir John.—Where is Sir John?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Sir John an't at home, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where is he?—where is he gone?—when did he go out?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I really don't know, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle, I know you fib now—But I'll ſift this to the bottom.—I'll write to my lady Conqueſt to know the truth about that girl that was here but now.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: You will find I told you truth, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Mrs. Pert,—I'll go and write this moment,—ſend Robert to me to give me an account of his maſter—Sir John, Sir John, you will diſtract me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! but that quickneſs, and that extreme ſenſibility is what I am afraid of.—I poſitively would not have a jealous huſband for the world—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: By heaven! no earthly circumſtance ſhall ever make me think injuriouſly of you.—Jealouſy!—ha! ha!—it is the moſt ridiculous paſſion—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You may laugh, Sir; but I know your over-refining temper too well, and I abſolutely will have it in our marriage-articles, that I muſt not be plagued with your ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſubſcribe, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
I will have no enquiries where I am going to viſit; no following me from place to place; and if we ſhould chance to meet, and you ſhould perceive a man of wit, or a pretty fellow,
ſpeaking to me, I will not have you fidgetting about on your chair, knitting your brow, and looking at your watch—My dear, is it not time to go home?—my love, the coach is waiting:—and then, if you are prevailed upon to ſtay, I will not have you converſe with a "yes, Sir," and a "no, Sir," for the reſt of the evening, and then wrangle with me in the chariot all the way home, and not be commonly civil to me for the reſt of the night—I poſitively will have none of this—.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Agreed, ma'am, agreed—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And then you ſhan't tell me you are going out of town, and then ſneak in privately to the play, or to Ranelagh, merely to be a ſpy upon me—and I poſitively will admit no curioſity about my letters—if you were to open a letter of mine, I ſhould never forgive you—I do verily believe, if you were to open my letters I ſhould hate you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſubſcribe to every thing you can aſk—you ſhall have what female friends you pleaſe; looſe your money to whom you pleaſe; dance with what beau you pleaſe; ride out with whom you pleaſe; go to what china ſhop you pleaſe; and, in ſhort, do what you pleaſe, without my attempting to bribe your footman, or your maid to—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! lud! Oh! lud! that is in the very ſtrain of jealouſy—Heaven deliver me!—there is my father yonder, and Sir William Bellmont with him—Fly—this inſtant, fly, Mr. Beverley, down that walk—any where—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You promiſe then—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Don't talk to me now—what would you be at?—I am yours, and only yours; unalterably
ſo—Fly—Mr. Beverley, be gone, and leave me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I obey, madam—I am gone.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Now are they putting their wiſe heads together to thwart all my ſchemes of happineſs—but love, imperious love, will have it otherwiſe—

div.stage: Enter Mr. BLANDFORD, and Sir WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, ſince we have agreed upon every thing—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Why yes, Mr. Blandford, I think every thing is ſettled—

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Why then we have only to acquaint the young people with our intentions, and ſo conclude the affair—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: That is all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: As to my girl, I don't mind her nonſenſe about Beverley—ſhe muſt do as I will have her.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And my ſon too, he muſt follow my directions.—As to his telling me of his love for Clariſſa, it is all a joke to me—Children muſt do as their parents will have them.—

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Ay! ay! ſo they muſt; and ſo they ſhall—hey! here is my daughter—So Belinda!—well, my girl, Sir William and I have agreed, and ſo you are to prepare for marriage, that's all—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Marriage with Mr. Beverley, Sir?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You know you encouraged him yourſelf, Sir—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p:
Well, well! I have changed my mind on that head—my friend, Sir William, here offers
you his ſon—do as I would have you—have a care, Belinda—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: But, madam, I will be obeyed—You don't like him, you ſay—but I like him—and that's ſufficient for you—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And ſo it is, Mr. Blandford;—if my ſon pretended to have a will of his own, I ſhould let him know to the contrary—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And can you, Sir William, againſt our inclination force us both?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Belinda; don't provoke me—What makes you from home?—go your ways back to Queen's-Square directly, and ſettle your mind; for I tell you once for all I will have my own way.—Come, Sir William, we will ſtep to the lawyer's chambers.—Go home, Belinda, and be obſervant of my commands.—Come along, Sir William—what did you ſay?—you mutiny, do you?—don't provoke me—You know, Belinda, I am an odd ſort of a man when provok'd—Look ye here—mind what I ſay; I won't reaſon with you about the matter; my power is abſolute, and if you offer to rebel, you ſhall have no huſband at all with my conſent—I'll cut you off with a ſhilling; I'll ſee you ſtarve—beg an alms—live miſerable—die wretched—in ſhort, ſuffer any calamity without the leaſt compaſſion from me—if I ſhould find you an undutiful girl at laſt—ſo there's one word for all—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
What will become of me?—his inhumanity overcomes me quite—I can never conſent—the very ſight of this picture is enough to forbid it—Oh! Beverley,—you are the maſter
of my heart—I'll go this inſtant—and—heavens! I can ſcarce move—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No tidings of her far or near—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How I tremble!—I ſhall fall—no help—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What do I ſee!—a young lady in diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh!—(faints in his arms, and drops the picture.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: She is fallen into a fit—Would my ſervants were in the way—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where can this barbarous man be gone to?—Ha!—under my very window!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: How cold ſhe is!—quite cold— (lays his hand to her cheek)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: How familiar he is with her!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And yet ſhe looks beautiful ſtill—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Does ſhe ſo?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Her eyes open—how lovely they look!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Traitor!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Her cheek begins to colour—well, young lady, how fare you now?—my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My dear, too—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Heavens! where am I?—In a ſtrange gentleman's arms all this time!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Repoſe yourſelf there, or will you ſtep into my houſe?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
No, truly, ſhan't ſhe—vile man!—But I will ſpoil your ſport—I will come
down to you directly, and flaſh confuſion in your face—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Where do you live, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: In Queen's-Square, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will wait upon you—truſt yourſelf with me—you look much better now—Lean on my arm—there, there, I will conduct you—

div.p: Now I'll make one among ye.—ha! fled! gone! which way?—is not that he, yonder?—no—he went into my houſe, I dare ſay, as I came down ſtairs—Tattle, Tattle, Robert,—will nobody anſwer—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where is Sir John?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: La! ma'am, how ſhould I know?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Did not he go in this moment?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: No, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: To be ſure you will ſay ſo—I'll follow him thro' the world, or I'll find him out—ſo, ſo—what is here?—this is her picture, I ſuppoſe—I will make ſure of this at leaſt—this will diſcover her to me, tho' ſhe has eſcaped now—The cruel, falſe, deceitful man!

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Poor lady! I believe her head is turned, for my part.—Well! I am determined I'll look out for another place, that's a ſure thing I will.—

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: ROBERT, where is your lady?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: In her own room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Any body with her?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I can't ſay, Sir—my lady is not well—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not well! fatigued with rioting about this town, I ſuppoſe—how long has ſhe been at home?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: About an hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: About an hour!—very well, Robert, you may retire— (Exit Robert)—now will I queſtion her cloſely—ſo—ſo—ſo—ſhe comes, leaning on her maid—finely diſſembled!—finely diſſembled!—But this pretended illneſs ſhall not ſhelter her from my ſtrict enquiry—Soft a moment!—If I could overhear what paſſes between 'em, it might lead to the truth—I'll work by ſtratagem—Oh! the hypocrite! how ſhe acts her part!—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: How are you now, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Somewhat better, Tattle—reach that chair—Tattle, tell me honeſtly, does that girl live with Lady Conqueſt?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: She does, madam, upon my veracity.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well! you will be obſtinate, I ſee, but I ſhall know the truth preſently; I ſhall have an anſwer from her ladyſhip, and then all will come out.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: You will hear nothing, Ma'am, but what I have told you already.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle, Tattle, I took you up in the country in hopes gratitude would make you my friend—but you are as bad as the reſt of them—conceal all you know, do;—it is of very little conſequence—I now ſee through the whole affair—though it is the picture of a man—yet I am not to be deceived—I underſtand it all.—This is ſome former gallant—the creature gave this to Sir John, as a proof that ſhe had no affection for any but himſelf.—What art he muſt have had to induce her to this!—I have found him out at laſt—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What does ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I have ſeen enough to convince me what a man he is—the fate of us poor women is hard—we all wiſh for huſbands, and they are the torments of our lives.—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: There is too much truth in what you ſay, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You join her, do you, Mrs. Iniquity?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a pity it is, Tattle, that poor women ſhould be under ſeverer reſtraints than the men are!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You repine for want of freedom, do you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
Cruel laws of wedlock!—The tyrant-huſband may triumph in his infidelity,
may ſecurely trample upon all laws of decency and order, and it redounds to his credit—gives him a faſhionable air of vice, while a poor woman is obliged to ſubmit to his cruelty—and remains tied to him for life—even though ſhe has reaſon to entertain a mortal hatred for him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! very well argued, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a pity it is, Tattle, that we cannot change our huſbands, as we do our ear-rings or our gloves!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There is a woman of ſpirit!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle! will you own the truth to me about that girl?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I really have told you the truth, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You won't diſcover, I ſee—very well!—you may go down ſtairs—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I aſſure your ladyſhip—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Go down ſtairs—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Would I had never ſeen my huſband's face!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I am even with you—I have as good wiſhes for you, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This picture here—Oh the baſe man!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture of her gallant, I ſuppoſe.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This is really a handſome picture—what a charming countenance!—It is perfumed I fancy—the ſcent is agreeable—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! the jade, how eagerly ſhe kiſſes it!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Why had not I ſuch a dear, dear man, inſtead of the brute, the monſter—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Monſter!—She does not mince the matter, but ſpeaks plain downright Engliſh—I muſt contain my rage, and ſteal upon her meditations—ſo—ſo—ſo—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: There is no falſhood in this look.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Looking over her ſhoulder.) Oh! what a handſome dog ſhe has choſen for herſelf!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: With you, I could be for ever happy—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You could, could you? (Snatches the picture.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: (Screams out.) Mercy on me!—Oh! is it you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, madam, now falſe one, have I caught you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You are come home at laſt, I find, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My lady Reſtleſs, my lady Reſtleſs, what can you ſay for yourſelf now?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What can I ſay for myſelf, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! Madam! this picture—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that picture.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Will be an evidence—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Of your ſhame Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Of my ſhame!—'tis very true what ſhe ſays;—yes, madam, it will be an evidence of my ſhame; I feel that but too ſenſibly;—but—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You own it then, do you?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Own it! I muſt own it, madam; though confuſion cover me, I muſt own it;—it is what you have deſerved at my hands—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
I deſerve it, Sir John!—but find excuſes if you will—cruel, cruel man!—to make
me this return at laſt—I cannot bear it—Oh! oh! (Cries.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! you may weep; but your tears are loſt; they will fall without effect.—I now renounce you for ever—this picture will juſtify me to the wide world; it will ſhew what a baſe woman you have been.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What does the man mean?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture of your gallant, madam!—the darling of your amorous hours,—who gratifies your luxurious appetites abroad, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Scurrilous wretch! Oh! Sir, you are at your old ſtratagem I find,—recrimination, you think, will ſerve your turn.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is a pity you know, madam, that a woman ſhould be tied to a man for life, even though ſhe has a mortal hatred for him.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Artful hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That ſhe can't change her huſband as ſhe does her ear-rings or her gloves.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Po! Sir John, this is your old device, this won't avail you.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Had the original of this fallen to your lot, you could kiſs the picture for ever.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir John.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You can gloat upon it, madam, glue your very lips to it.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Shallow artifice!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: With him you could be for ever happy.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This is all in vain, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Had ſuch a dear, dear man fallen to your lot, inſtead of the brute, the monſter—Am I a monſter?—I am,—and you have made me ſo—the world ſhall know your infamy.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! brave it out, Sir, brave it out to the laſt—harmleſs, innocent man!—you have nothing to bluſh for, nothing to be aſhamed of—you have no intrigues, no private amours abroad—I have not ſeen any thing, not I—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, I have ſeen, and I now ſee your paramour.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! that air of confidence will be of great uſe to you, Sir—for you have no convenient to meet you under my very window, to loll ſoftly in your arms—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Hey! how!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Her arm thrown careleſsly round your neck—your hand tenderly applied to her cheek.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: S'death! that's unlucky—ſhe will turn it againſt me. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! you are in confuſion, are you, Sir?—but why ſhould you? you meant no harm—You are ſafe with me, my dear—will you ſtep into my houſe, my love?—yes, Sir, you would fain bring her into my very houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My Lady Reſtleſs, this evaſion is mean and paultry—you beheld a young lady in diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! I know it, Sir,—and you, tender-hearted man, could careſs her out of meer compaſſion;—gaze wantonly on her out of charity, and, out of pure benevolence of diſpoſition, convey her to ſome convenient dwelling—Oh! Sir John, Sir John—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, this well-acted paſſion—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't imagine ſhe has eſcaped me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! you may talk and rave, ma'am; but depend upon it, I ſhall ſpare no pains to do
myſelf juſtice on this occaſion—nor will I reſt till—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! fie upon you, Sir John; theſe artifices—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN
sp.p: Nor will I reſt, madam, until I have found, by means of this inſtrument here in my hand, who your darling is—I will go about ſtreight—ungrateful, treacherous woman!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, go now, under that pretext, in purſuit of your licentious pleaſures.—This ever has been his ſcheme to cloak his wicked practices—abandoned man!—To face me down too, after what my eyes ſo plainly beheld—I wiſh I could wring that ſecret out of Tattle—I'll ſtep to my own room directly, and try by menaces, by wheedling, by fair means, by foul means, by every means, to wreſt it from her.

div.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, and ROBERT after him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Come hither, Robert—look at this picture—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me watch his countenance—well! well!—doſt thou know it, Robert?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: 'Tis a mighty handſome picture, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A handſome picture!— (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: The fineſt lady in the land need not deſire a handſomer man, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: How well he knows the purpoſes of it!—well! well! honeſt Robert, tell me,—well—who is it?—tell me—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
You know whoſe picture that is—
I know you do—well! well! who—who—who is it?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I don't know—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not know!—but I am convinced you know—ſo own the truth—don't be a villain—don't—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: As I am an honeſt man, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Be an honeſt man then, and tell me—did you never ſee ſuch a ſmooth faced, fiery eyed, warm-complexioned, taper young fellow here about my houſe?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Never, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. JOHN.
sp.p: Not with my wife!—to drink chocolate of a morning, tea of an evening—come, honeſt Robert—I'll give you a leaſe of a good farm—come, what ſay you?—a leaſe for your life—well! well!—you may take your wife's life into the bargain—well!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir John, I never ſaw—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll add your child's life—come ſpeak out—your own life, your wife's life, and your child's—now! now! a leaſe for three lives you have—now, Robert!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy I never ſaw any ſuch perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, Robert, you are bribed by my wife—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, as I am a ſinner, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And the worſt of ſinners you will be, if you are a confederate in this plot againſt my peace and honour.—Reflect on that Robert.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: Pray does not Sir John Reſtleſs live ſomewhere hereabout?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He does, friend; what is your buſineſs with him?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: My buſineſs is with his lady—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I gueſſed as much. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I have a letter here for my lady Reſtleſs, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A letter for my lady!—from whom, pray?—

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: From my lord Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My lord Conqueſt! very well, friend—you may give the letter to me—I am Sir John Reſtleſs—that there is my houſe—let me have the letter—I will take care of it.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I was ordered to deliver it into my lady's own hand.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The devil you was—I muſt have the letter—I'll buy it of the raſcal— (aſide)—here take this for your trouble, friend, (gives him money) and I'll take care of the letter—

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I humbly thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now—now—now—let me ſee what this is—now my lady Reſtleſs—now falſe-one, now— (reads.)

body.p: My lady Conqueſt being gone into the country for a few days, I have judged it proper to ſend a ſpeedy anſwer to yours, and to aſſure you, for your peace of mind, that you need not entertain the leaſt ſuſpicion of Marmalet, my lady's woman. She has lived ſome years in our family, and I know her by experience to be an honeſt truſty girl, and one that would not make miſchief between your ladyſhip and Sir John.

closer.signed: I have the honour to be, Madam, your very humble ſervant, CONQUEST.

sp.p: So! ſo! ſo!—Marmalet is a truſty girl!—one that will not make miſchief between man and wife!—that is to ſay, now that ſhe will diſcover nothing againſt my lady Reſtleſs!—for her peace of mind he lets madam know all this too!—ſhe may go on boldly now; for my lady Conqueſt is gone into the country, Marmalet is truſty, and my lord has given her the moſt ſpeedy notice—Very well! very well!—proofs thicken upon proofs—Shall I go directly and challenge his lordſhip?—no—no—that won't do—Watch him cloſely, that will do better—If I could have a word in private with the maid—Robert,—Robert—come hither—ſtep to my lord Conqueſt's—but with caution proceed—Enquire there for Marmalet, the maid.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I know her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He knows her—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: She viſits our Tattle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Viſits our Tattle!—it is a plain caſe— (aſide)—Enquire for that girl—but with caution, tho'—and tell her to meet me privately—unknown to any body—in the duſk of the evening—down in the Bird-Cage walk, yonder.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And don't let Tattle ſee her—Tattle has engaged her in her miſtreſs's intereſt—I ſee how it is—don't let any of my ſervants ſee her—go directly, Robert. Now ſhall I judge what regard you have for me—But, hark ye, Robert!—Come hither! a word with you—ſhould it be known that this girl converſes with me—ſhould my lady have the leaſt item of it, they are then upon their guard—You muſt be cautious, therefore—let her come wrapped up in darkneſs—concealed from every obſerver with a maſk on—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: A maſk, Sir John—won't that make her be remark'd the more?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, let her come maſked; I will make every thing ſure—Robert, bring this about for me, and I am your friend for ever—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I will do my endeavour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll now take a turn round the Park, and try if I can find the minion this picture belongs to—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, they had almoſt ſurpriz'd us—but at ſight of her father, Belinda gave me the word, and away I darted down towards the canal, yonder—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Was Sir William with him then?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes; they had been plotting our deſtruction together—But we ſhall out-officer them, it is to be hoped, my boy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, and it is alſo to be feared that we ſhall not.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Hey! you alarm me—no new mine ſprung!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, nothing new; but the old ſtory—The old folks are determined;—at the turning of yonder corner they came both full tilt upon Clariſſa, and me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, and how! what paſſed?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why they were ſcarcely civil to your ſiſter. Sir William fixed his ſurly eye upon me for a time, then calling me to him, Sir, ſays he, you will run counter to my will, I ſee—you will be ever dangling after that girl—But, Mr. Blandford and I have agreed upon the match,—and then he peremptorily commanded me to take my leave of her that moment.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And did you ſo?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And did you ſo?—how can you aſk ſuch a queſtion? Sir, ſays I, I muſt ſee the lady home, and ſo off I marched, arm in arm, with her, my father bawling after me, and I bowing to him, Sir, your humble ſervant, I wiſh you a good morning, Sir.—He continued calling out,—I kiſſed my hand to him,—and ſo we made our eſcape.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And where have you left her?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At home; at your houſe.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! and do ye both continue in the ſame mind; is to-morrow to be your weddingday?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now are you conjuring up a thouſand horrid fancies to torment yourſelf with—But don't be alarmed, my dear Beverley—I ſhall leave you your Belinda, and content myſelf with the honour of being your brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, the honour will be to me—But uneaſy!—ha! ha!—no—no—I am not uneaſy, nor ſhall I ever be ſo again—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wiſh you would keep that reſolution—where do you dine?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Will you dine with me?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I can't; 'tis club-day—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Faith, ſo it is—I'll attend you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That's right; let us turn towards the Mall, and ſaunter there till dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, I can't go that way yet—I muſt enquire how Belinda does, and what her father ſaid to her; for I have not ſeen her ſince we parted in the morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
And now, according to cuſtom, you will make her an apology for leaving her, when there was an abſolute neceſſity for it, and you'll
fall to an explanation of circumſtances that require no explanation at all, and refine upon things, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Nay, if you begin with your raillery, I am off—your ſervant—a l'honneur—

Poor Beverley!—Tho' a handſome fellow, and of agreeable talents, he has ſuch a ſtrange diffidence in himſelf, and ſuch a ſolicitude to pleaſe, that he is every moment of his life moſt ingeniouſly elaborating his own uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not yet, not yet; nobody like it as yet—ha!—who is that hovering about my houſe?—if that ſhould be he now!—I'll examine him nearer—Pray, Sir—what the devil ſhall I ſay?—Pray, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I beg pardon for troubling you, Sir—but pray what o'clock is it by your watch?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By my watch, Sir!—I'll let you know in a moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me examine him now— (looks at him, and then at the picture.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Egad, I am afraid my watch is not right—it muſt be later—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not like him— (comparing them both)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It does not go, I am afraid— (puts it to his ear.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The eye—no!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, Sir, by my watch it wants a quarter of three.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not he—and yet—no—no—no—I am ſtill to ſeek—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Hip! Bellmont—well overtaken—a word with you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Here comes another;—they are all ſwarming about my houſe—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have ſeen her; I have ſeen Belinda, my boy—ſhe will be with Clariſſa in the Park immediately after dinner, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I want to ſee his face; this may be the original.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Her father has been rating her in his uſual manner; but your marriage with my ſiſter will ſettle every thing.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll walk round him (ſings) Loll toll loll— (locks at him)—ha! it has his air— (ſings) Loll toll loll,—and it has his eye—Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee, Bellmont, don't be ſuch a danggling lover, but conſummate at once, prithee do, for the ſake of your friends.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It has his noſe for all the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, Beverley, do you ſpirit your ſiſter up to keep her reſolution, and tomorrow puts you out of all pain—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: —Loll toll loll—it has his complexion—the ſame glowing, hot, amorous complexion—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Who is this gentleman walking here?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know—an odd fellow he ſeems to be—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Loll toll loll—it has his ſhoulders—Loll toll loll—ay, and I fancy the mole upon
the cheek too—I wiſh I could view him nearer—Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The man ſeems mad, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Begging your pardon, Sir—Pray (looking at him and the picture)—Pray, Sir, can you tell whether we ſhall have a Spaniſh war?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Not I, truly; did you ever ſee ſuch an odd fellow, Bellmont?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: He has been talking to me too: he is too well dreſſed for a poet.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Not, if he has had a good ſubſcription.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has the mole ſure enough—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Let us ſtep this way—I have more to ſay to you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! he wants to ſneak off—Guilt! guilt! conſcious guilt!—I'll make ſure of him tho'—pray, Sir,—I beg your pardon—is not your name Wildair?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, Sir, Beverley, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Have you no relation of that name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very like a gentleman of that name—a friend of mine, whoſe picture I have here—will you give me leave juſt to— compares him with the picture.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: An odd adventure this, Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Very odd, indeed.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Do you find any likeneſs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your head a little more that way, if you pleaſe—ay! ay! it is he—'tis a plain caſe; this is my man, or rather,—this is my wife's man—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Did you ever know any thing like this?—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: They are both laughing at me—ay! and I ſhall be laught at by the whole town, pointed at, hooted at, and gazed at—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What do I ſee?—s'death, the ſetting of that picture is like what I gave Belinda.—Zoons! if it is the ſame—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He makes his approach,—and means, I ſuppoſe, to ſnatch it out of my hand—But I'll be before-hand with him,—and ſo into my pocket it goes—There, lie ſafe there—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Zoons! he puts it up in a hurry—will you be ſo good, Sir, as to favour me with a—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh you a good day—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: With a ſight of that picture for a moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture, Sir—Po!—a mere daub—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Mere curioſity, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not worth your ſeeing—I wiſh you a good day.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſhould take it as a favour—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A paltry thing—I have not a moment to ſpare—my family waiting dinner—Sir, I wiſh you a good morning— (runs into his houſe.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Death and fire! Bellmont, my picture—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! no—no ſuch thing—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I am ſure of it—if Belinda—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What, relapſing into uneaſineſs and ſuſpicion again!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I have reaſon to be uneaſy—ſhe ſlights me, diſdains me,—treats me with contempt—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But I tell you, that unhappy temper of yours—Prithee, man, leave teazing yourſelf, and let us adjourn to dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, Sir; I ſhan't dine at all—I am not well—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ridiculous! how can you be ſo abſurd?—I'll bett you twenty pounds that is not your picture—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Done; I take it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: With all my heart; and I'll tell you what, if it be yours, I will give you leave to be as jealous of her as you pleaſe—Come, now let us to dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I attend you—in the evening we ſhall know the truth—if it be that I gave Belinda—ſhe is falſe, and I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN,
sp.p: There he goes—there he goes—the deſtroyer of my peace and happineſs!—I'll follow him, and make ſure that he has given me his name rightly,—and then, my Lady Reſtleſs, I have done with you for ever.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: BUT have you really fixed every thing, Clariſſa?

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Poſitively, and to-morrow morning makes me his.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To-morrow morning!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Yes, to-morrow morning I releaſe Mr. Bellmont from his fetters, and reſign my perſon to him.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why, that is what all we poor women, after all the victories of our charms, all the triumphs of our beauty, and all the murders of our eyes, muſt come to at laſt.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, and in that we but imitate the men. Don't we read of them conquering whole kingdoms, and then ſubmitting at laſt to be governed by the vanquiſhed.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very true, Clariſſa; and upon my word I think you are a heroine equal in fame to any of them; nay ſuperior, for your ſcheme, I take it, is not to unpeople the world—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Prithee, Belinda, don't talk ſo wildly; for, to tell you the truth, now that I have ſettled the affair, I begin to be alarmed at what I have done.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! dear, dear affectation!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Actually now, poſitively, I am terrified to death.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—to be ſure—our ſex muſt play its tricks, and ſummon up all its fantaſtic train of doubts and fears—but courage, my dear, don't be frightened, for the ſame ſex within that heart of yours will urge you on, and never let you be at reſt, till you have procured yourſelf a tyrant for life.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: A tyrant, Belinda! I think more generouſly of Mr. Bellmont, than to imagine he will uſurp to himſelf an ill uſe of his power—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To deal candidly with you, I am of your opinion—but, tell me now, a'n't I a very good girl, to reſign ſuch a man to you?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Why, indeed, I muſt confeſs the obligation.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! but to reſign him for one, whoſe temper does not promiſe I ſhall live under ſo mild a government.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: How do you mean?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Beverley's ſtrange caprices, ſuſpicions, and unaccountable whimſies, are enough to alarm one upon the brink of matrimony.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I vow I can't help thinking, Belinda, that you are a little ſubject to vain ſurmiſes and ſuſpicions yourſelf.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Come now, you are an inſincere girl; you know I am of a temper too generous, too open—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: I grant all that, but by this conſtant repetition of the ſame doubts, I ſhould not wonder to ſee you moſt heartily jealous of him—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Jealous!—oh heavens!—jealous indeed!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I ſay no more; and as to my brother, here he comes, and let him ſpeak for himſelf.—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, upon my ſoul, Beverley, you make me laugh at you—but come, there's an end of that matter—Ladies your moſt obedient—I hope we have not tranſgreſſed our time.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt; you are both very exact—true as the dial to the ſun.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (In a peeviſh manner.) Although it be not ſhone upon.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Although it be not ſhone upon, Mr. Beverley!—why with that dejected air, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! lord! you two are going to commence wrangling lovers again—a-propos, Belinda—now Beverley, you ſhall ſee—be ſo good, ma'am, as to let me ſee this gentleman's picture.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: His picture! what can you want it for?—you ſhall have it— (ſearching her pocket.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now, Beverley, do you confeſs how wrong you have been?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Why faith I begin to think I was wrong—ſay not a word to her—ſhe'll never forgive me elſe. (Apart.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: It is not in that pocket—it muſt be here— (ſearches the other.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You have been ſad company, on account of this ſtrange ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I own it; let it drop; ſay no more.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Well! I proteſt and vow—what can
become of it? come, gentlemen, this is ſome trick of yours—you have it among ye—Mr. Bellmont, Mr. Beverley—pray return it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, ma'am, it is no trick of ours— (angrily.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: As I live and breathe I have not got it.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What think you now, Bellmont?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She'll find it preſently, man; don't ſhew your humours, be upon your guard; you'll undo yourſelf elſe—Clariſſa, ſhall you and I ſaunter down this walk?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: My brother ſeems out of humour,—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll tell you preſently—let us ſtep this way.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, I declare upon my honour I don't know what is come of this odious picture—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This odious picture!—Oh! Belinda.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You may look grave, Sir, but I have it not.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I know you have not, ma'am; and don't imagine—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Imagine! what do you mean?—imagine what?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't imagine that I am to be led blindfold as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! heavens! with what gravity that was ſaid!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am not to be deceived; I can ſee all around me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You can?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I can, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, and how do you like your proſpect?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! you begin to banter—but that picture I have ſeen this day in the hands of another—the gentleman to whom you gave it.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To whom I gave it!—have a care, Sir; this is another ſymptom of your jealous temper.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I tell you, madam, I ſaw it in his hand.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who is the gentleman?—what's his name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: That I can't ſay—I—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, upon my word you are making yourſelf very ridiculous in this matter—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may laugh, madam, but it is no laughing matter, I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! brave—follow your own notions—I gave it away—I have ſcorned your preſent—ha! ha!—poor Mr. Beverley!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I don't doubt you, ma'am, I believe you did give it away.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir,—think ſo if you pleaſe—I ſhall leave you to your own imagination—it will find wherewithal to entertain you—ha! ha! your ſervant, Sir,—yonder I ſee Clariſſa and Mr. Bellmont—I will join them this inſtant—your ſervant, Sir,—amuſe yourſelf with your own fancies—ha! ha!

div.p:
Damnation!—I can't tell what to make of this.—She carries it of with an air of confidence; and yet if that be my picture, which I ſaw this
morning, then it is plain I am only laught at by her—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Obſerve him now—let us walk by him without taking any notice of him—and ſo—let us talk of any thing rather than be ſilent—What a charming evening!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And how gay the park looks!—mind the gentleman!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Take no notice; I beg you won't—Suppoſe we were to ſhew ourſelves in the Mall, Clariſſa, and walk our charms there, as the French expreſs it!—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Beverley!—what fixed in contemplation!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I beg—I chuſe to be alone, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEL. BELIN. CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pſhaw! fooliſh!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! for heaven's ſake—let us indulge the gentleman—let us leave him to himſelf, and his ill humouts—this way—this way—you ſhall go home and have your tea with me—Mr. Beverley (ſhe kiſſes her hand to him at ſome diſtance, and laughs at him) your ſervant, Sir—I wiſh you a good evening—your ſervant, Sir—

Zoons! I can't bear all this—if ſhe has parted with the picture—if ſhe has given it away—but ſhe may only have lent it, or ſhe may have
loſt it—but even that, even that is an injury to me—why ſhould ſhe not be more careful of it?—I will know the bottom of it—that's the houſe the gentleman went into—I'll wait on him directly—but they are watching me—I'll walk off another way, to elude their obſervation—ay! ay! you may laugh, ma'am, but I ſhall find you out.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at Sir John's.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where are you going, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: To my maſter's room, madam, to leave theſe cloaths there.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Stay, Sir;—ſtay a moment (ſearches the pockets)—Where are his letters?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Letters, my lady!—I know of no letters—I never touch his pockets—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I gueſſed you would ſay ſo—you are Sir John's agent—the conductor of his ſchemes.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I, madam!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You, Sir,—you are his ſecretary for love affairs.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I collect his rents, my lady, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I am not to be deceived—I know you for my enemy.—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Enemy, ma'am!—I am ſure, as far as a poor ſervant dare, I am a friend to both—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Then tell me honeſtly, have not you conveyed his letters out of my way?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, not I—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Then he has done it himſelf—artful man!—I never can find a line after him—where did you go for him this morning?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: This morning!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay! this morning—I know he ſent you ſomewhere—Where was it?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, my lady—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—I ſee how it is—you are all bent againſt me—I ſhall never be at reſt till every ſervant in this houſe is of my own chuſing.—Is Tattle come home yet?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where can ſhe be gadding about? Hark!—I hear a rap at the door—this is Sir John, I ſuppoſe—ſtay, let me liſten—I don't know that voice—who can it be—ſome of his libertine company, I ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: My lady, if you will believe me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, man—let me hear—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, I ſay!—won't you hold your tongue?—go about your buſineſs, Sir, go about your buſineſs—What does he ſay? (liſtening) I can't hear a word—Who's below there?

div.stage: Enter TATTLE, with a Capuchin on.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: So Mrs. Tattle—who is that at the door?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: A gentleman, madam, ſpeaking to William.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And where have you been, miſtreſs?—How dare you go out without my leave—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, don't be angry with me—I was ſo terrified about what happened in the morning; and your ladyſhip was in ſuch a perilous taking about it, that I went to deſire Mrs. Marmalet would juſtify herſelf and me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! very well, Mrs. Buſy-Body—you have been there, have you?—You have been to frame a ſtory among yourſelves, have you, and to hinder me from diſcovering?—But I'll go to my Lady Conqueſt myſelf—I have had no anſwer to my letter, and 'tis you have occaſioned it—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, if you will but give me leave—I have been doing you the greateſt piece of ſervice—I believe, in my conſcience, there is ſomething in what you ſuſpect about Sir John—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you?—why?—how?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I have ſeen Mrs. Marmalet, and I have made ſuch a diſcovery—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Have you Tattle?—what?—ſpeak—tell me—what is it?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Robert has been there, madam, with a meſſage from Sir John, who wants to ſee her in the evening; and he has deſired—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Bleſſings on you, Tattle—well—go on—tell me all—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What do you want, Sir?—who called you?—go about your buſineſs—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Madam, there is a gentleman wants to ſpeak with Sir John about a picture—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I had forgot me—it was he rapped at the door, I ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: About a picture!—this may lead to ſome further diſcovery—deſire the gentleman to ſtep up ſtairs— (Exit Servant)—and ſo Tattle, Robert has been there—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And Sir John wants to ſpeak with Marmalet in the evening, and has deſired—Oh! the baſe man!—what has he deſired?—now he is diſcovered—what has he deſired?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: He has deſired, ma'am—the poor girl does not know what to make of it—She is very ſober and diſcreet, I aſſure you, ma'am—he has deſired, ma'am, in the duſk of the evening, that Mrs. Marmalet will come and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: How unlucky this is?—the gentleman is coming—I have a mind not to ſee him—and yet I will too—Tattle, do you ſtep to my room; as ſoon as he goes, I will come to you, and hear all in private.— (Exit Tattle) In the duſk of the evening he deſires to ſee her—abandoned wretch!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I wanted a word with Sir John Reſtleſs, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: About a picture, the ſervant tells me, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, madam, a picture I had given to a lady; and however inſignificant in itſelf, it is to me of the higheſt conſequence, as it may conduce to the explanation of an affair, in which the happineſs of my life is concerned.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: The lady is young?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And handſome?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: In the higheſt degree; my heart is devoted to her; and I have reaſon to ſuſpect, that a preſent from me is not of ſo much value as I could wiſh.—To be plain, ma'am, I imagine ſhe has given the picture away.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Look-ye there now!—my ſuſpicions are juſt.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your ſuſpicions, madam!—did you ſuſpect it was given to Sir John Reſtleſs?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What I know of the matter ſhall be no ſecret to you—Pray, Sir, have you ſpoke to the lady on this head?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have, but ſhe knows nothing of the matter; ſhe has loſt it,—ſhe has miſlaid it,—ſhe can give no account of it—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: She has given it to Sir John, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Given it to him?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Given it to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Then I have no further doubt.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I would not hurt your peace of mind; I would not give you impreſſions of Sir John, that may—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, ſtand upon no ceremony with him; an injurious, falſe, licentious man!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Is that his character?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Notoriouſly: he has made me miſerable; falſe to his marriage vows, and warm in the purſuit of his pleaſures abroad!—I have not deſerved it of him—Oh! Sir John! Sir John! Oh!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She weeps; the caſe is plain, and I am undone—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is the lady's name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda Blandford.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Belinda Blandford!—I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, have you ever ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Seen her, Sir!—yes, I have ſeen too much of her.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You alarm me, madam—you have ſeen nothing unhandſome, I hope—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I don't know what you call unhandſome, Sir.—But, pray, what ought one to think of a young lady thrown familiarly into a gentleman's arms?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: In his arms, madam!—Sir John's arms!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In Sir John's!—in open day;—in the Park;—under my very window;—moſt familiarly, wantonly reclining in his very arms.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! heavens!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: He claſping her with equal freedom round the waiſt—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Falſe, falſe Belinda!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Both interchanging fond mutual glances—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, the whole is come to light, and I thank you for the diſcovery, tho' I am ruined by it—But give me leave—is all this certain?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: There can be no doubt, Sir, theſe eyes beheld their amorous meeting.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Saw it yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, all, all, Sir—Sir John, I know, is capable of any thing, and you know what to think of Belinda, as you call her.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, I have long had reaſon to ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You have, Sir?—then the whole affair is plain enough.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It is ſo—I meant an honourable connection with her;—but—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: But you ſee, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, I ſee, madam—you are ſure Sir John has this picture?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sure, Sir!—it is your own picture—I had it in my hands but a moment, and he flew with ardor, with impetuoſity, like a fury flew to it, and recovered it from me—what could be the meaning of that, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The meaning is too plain.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And then, Sir, when charged and preſſed home with his guilt, moſt hypocritically he pretended to believe it the portrait of ſome favourite of mine—But you know, Sir, how that is—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, I can juſtify you—ha! ha! that is but a poor evaſion, and confirms me the more in my opinion—and I humbly take my leave—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad you have had the good luck to ſpeak to me about this affair;—and, if any other circumſtances come to your knowledge, I ſhall take it as a favour if you will acquaint me with them—for, indeed, Sir, I am very unhappy—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I am in gratitude bound to you, and my beſt ſervices, you ſhall ever command—Madam, your moſt obedient—Oh! Belinda! Belinda!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
Now, Sir John—how will you be able to confront theſe ſtubborn facts?—You
are now ſeen thro' all your diſguiſes—detected in your true colours—Tattle within here, has freſh proofs againſt you, and your man Robert, and all of you,—I muſt hear that whole ſtory directly—

div.p: Yes, yes,—he told me his name honeſtly enough—Beverley is his name—and my lady Reſtleſs, now your gallant, your paramour, is known—What do I ſee?—By all my wrongs, the very man again!—coming out of my houſe before my face—
div.stage: BEVERLEY and ROBERT come out of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: There, friend, there is ſomething for your trouble.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He bribes my ſervant too;—and the fellow takes it—Both in their trade; both in their trade!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Could I have ſuſpected her of ſuch treachery—Zoons! I take that to be Sir John Reſtleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is he to whom I have ſo many obligations.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well encountered, Sir—your ſervant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My ſervant, Sir!—I rather take it you are my lady's ſervant.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
You, if I don't miſtake, Sir John, are a pretty general ſervant of the ladies.—Pray,
Sir, have not you a picture of mine in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That, I ſuppoſe, you have heard from my good lady within here—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I have heard a great deal more from my lady.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I don't in the leaſt doubt it.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I do not mean to work myſelf up into any choler about ſuch a trifling bauble—ſince the lady has thought proper to give it to you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Do her juſtice, pray; ſhe did not give it; ſo far ſhe was true to you—I took it from her, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And that ſhews you are upon free and eaſy terms with her;—it is of no manner of conſequence to me; I deſpiſe it, and you are welcome to make what uſe you will of it.—This, I will only ſay, that you have made me miſerable.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What, I have interrupted your happineſs?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And no doubt you think it cruel of me ſo to do.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Call it by what name you will,—you have ruined me with the woman I doated on to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A candid declaration!—and ſo, Sir, you doated on her, and never reflected that you were doing me the leaſt injury?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Injury!—I promiſe you, Sir, I will never injure you again, and ſo you may ſet your mind at peace, for I here declare, I never will hold farther intercourſe with her—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! that is too late for me; I have now done with her myſelf—you are very welcome to the lady, Sir—you may take her home with you as ſoon as you pleaſe; I have done with her, I forſwear her, and ſo I ſhall tell my lady this moment— (going.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: That will make her ladyſhip happy, no doubt—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay you know it will—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She told me as much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: She did!—why then you may depend I ſhall keep my word, and my lady may depend upon it too—and that I hope, with all my heart, will make you happy, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It won't indeed, Sir—I reſign her for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What, are you tired of her—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I loath her, deteſt her, hate her as much as I ever loved her.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And ſo do I too, I aſſure you—and ſo I ſhall tell my lady this very inſtant—your ſervant, Sir—and, if I can find proof ſufficient, you ſhall hear of me, I promiſe you, Sir— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: BEVERLEY.
sp.p: Ay! ſhe has been connected with him, till ſhe has pall'd his very appetite—s'death, I'll ſeek her this moment, upbraid her with her falſhood,—and even ſo—by heavens! I ſhall do it with regret—for even now I feel a tug at my heartſtring—but were I to be torn piece-meal, this ſhall be our laſt interview—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Alas a-day! poor ſoul! ſee where he takes his melancholy walk—did not I tell you, Clariſſa, that the ſtricken deer could not quit this place?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And did not I tell you, Belinda, that you could not keep away from the purſuit?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, ma'am, do you want to be in at the death, or do you mean to bring the poor thing to life again?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I!—what do you mean?—you bring me this way—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well! if that is the caſe, we had as good go home to your houſe, for I want my tea—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Po! not yet—it is not ſix o'clock.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What do ye laugh at?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: At you, my dear—why, 'tis paſt ſeven—Oh! Belinda, you are the ſtricken deer, I find—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who I?—not I truly—I—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: My dear Belinda, you are—and come, we will do the good natured thing by you,—and leave you to yourſelves—Succeſs attend you—come, Mr. Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Thyrſis, a youth of the inſpired train, Fair Sachariſſa lov'd, but lov'd in vain.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! (looking peeviſhly at her.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What, won't you know me, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I know you—it is but too true, that I know you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Prithee, give over theſe humours—what, ſtill gloomy and diſcontented!—come, come, under pain of my diſpleaſure, brighten up this moment.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po!—ſilly, ridiculous, and idle!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Come, come, when I proclaim a pardon, you had better embrace it, than reduce yourſelf to the neceſſity of ſighing, vowing, proteſting, writing to me, following me up and down, kneeling at my feet, imploring forgiveneſs—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhall never be brought to forgive—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! you may laugh, ma'am, you have too long impoſed upon my fond, eaſy credulity; but the witchery of your charms is over—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well, Sir! and you are your own man again.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am, madam, and you may be your own woman again, or any body's woman, or every body's—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You grow rude, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It is time to wave all ceremony, and to tell you plainly, that your falſhood—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My falſhood, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your falſhood!—I know the whole affair—I loved you once, Belinda, tenderly loved you, and by heaven I ſwear, it is with ſorrow that I can no longer adore you, and that I now bid you an everlaſting farewel— (going.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Explain, Sir—what action of my life?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your prudence forſook you at laſt—it was too glaring—too manifeſt in open day—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Too manifeſt in open day!—Mr. Beverley, I ſhall hate you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, all circumſtances inform againſt you—my picture given away—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Inſolent! provoking! wrong-headed man! I'll confirm him in his error, to torment him (aſide.)—Well, Sir, what if I choſe to give it away!—I am miſtreſs of my own actions, am I not?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
