sp.p: Oh! I know that, ma'am—I know that—and I am not uneaſy, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: So it ſeems—ha! ha!—why do you ſigh, poor man?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sigh, madam!—I diſdain it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I am glad of it; now that is ſo manly! but pray watch yourſelf well, hold a guard upon all your paſſions, otherwiſe they will make a fool of you again—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And do you take care you don't expoſe yourſelf again—lolling familiarly in a gentleman's arms!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Here, in the Park!—in open day!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What can this be?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: He inviting you to his houſe!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! I underſtand him now,—when I fainted, all this was—I'll encourage his notion, to be revenged of his waſpiſh temper (aſide.)—Well, Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What then?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Ha! ha!—poor Mr. Beverley!—why ſhould you be in a piteous taking, becauſe I, in the gaiety of my heart, give away a picture I ſet no value on, or walk with a gentleman I do
ſet a value on, or lean on his arm, or make the man happy by letting him draw on my glove—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Or draw off your glove, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! or draw it off—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, or—or—or take any other liberties—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very true—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may make light of it, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why yes, a generous temper always makes light of the favours it confers—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And ſome generous tempers will make light of any thing to gratify their inclinations—Madam, I have done—I abjure you—eternally abjure you.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Bon voyage!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't think to ſee me again—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Adieu!—Well, what, coming again—what, lingering— (repeats affectedly)
Thus o'er the dying lamp, the unſteady flame
Hangs quivering to a point—&c.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: With what an air ſhe carries it—I have but this one thing more to tell you—by heaven I loved you—to exceſs I loved you—ſuch is my weakneſs, I ſhall never quite forget you—I ſhall be glad, if hereafter I hear of your happineſs, and, if I can, no diſhonour ſhall fall on you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—well! my obliging, generous Don Quixote, go and ſight windmills, caſtles in the air, and a thouſand phantoms of your own creation, for your Dulcinea's ſake, do—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Confuſion!—mind, madam—that this is the laſt time of my troubling you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I ſhall expect you to-morrow morning—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—never—by heaven, never—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Exactly at ten—your uſual hour—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: May I periſh at your feet, if I do—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! brave—but remember ten—kneeling, beſeeching, imploring, your hand upon your heart, "Belinda, won't you forgive me?—"

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Damnation!—I have done—I here bid you an eternal adieu!—farewel—

sp.speaker: BELIN.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: SCENE, an Apartment in Beverley's Houſe.

sp.p: SO! ſo! ſo! Belinda, I have eſcaped your ſnares, and have recovered my freedom;—and yet, if ſhe had not proved falſe, what a treaſure of love had I in ſtore for all that beauty!—Po! po! no more of her beauty—it is external, ſuperficial, the mere reſult of features and complexion—A deceitful Syren, to draw the unwary into a dream of happineſs, and then wake him into wonder at the ſtorms and tempeſts that gather round him.—I have done with her; I'll think no more of her—Oh! Belinda! Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She that in every part of life ſeemed ſo amiable!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Under ſo fair a maſk to wear ſuch looſe deſigns!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: What is he muſing upon?—Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done with her for ever—ay, for ever— (hums a tune)—I ſwear for ever— (ſings)—are you there, Bruſh?—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, your honour—here is a letter.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: So unforeſeen, ſo unexpected a diſcovery!—Well! well! well!—what did you ſay, Bruſh?—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: A letter for your honour, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, give it to me another time—I'll not make myſelf uneaſy about her—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: I fancy your honour will be glad to have it now—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What did you ſay?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: It is a letter from madam Belinda, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda! I won't read it—take it away—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Hey! which way is the wind now?—ſome quarrel, I ſuppoſe—but the falling out of lovers—muſt I take it away, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done with her for ever.—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Have done with madam Belinda, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Bruſh, ſhe is—but I will not proclaim her ſhame—no, let me ſtill be tender—I will ſee her no more, Bruſh, that is all; hear from her no more; ſhe muſt not wind herſelf about my heart again—I'll go out of town directly—order my chaiſe to the door.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Had you not better deſer it till morrow morning, Sir? perhaps then—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—no—directly—do as I bid you—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir, if your mind ſhould change, the trouble of coming back poſt-haſte—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—never—I ſay, never—what to her? Who could ſmile on me, on him, on a thouſand—no,—no—ſhe ſhall know that I am a man—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p:
But, Sir, you know that one ſolitary tear, which, after miſerably chaſing for it for half an hour together, ſhe will painfully diſtil from
the corner of her eye, will extinguiſh all this rage, and then—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! you know nothing of the matter—go, and order the chaiſe directly—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I ſuppoſe a couple of ſhirts will be ſufficient, Sir?—you will hardly ſtay them out—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pack up all, Sir—I ſhall ſtay in the country a whole month, if it be neceſſary—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: An entire month, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am reſolved, fixed, determined,—and ſo, do as I have ordered you.— (Exit Bruſh)—So ſhall I diſentangle myſelf from her entirely—ſo ſhall I forget the fondneſs my fooliſh heart had for her—I hate her, loath her, pity her, am ſorry for her, and love her ſtill—I muſt expel this weakneſs from my mind—I will think no more of her—and yet—Bruſh! Bruſh!—I may as well ſee her letter too—only to try what her cunning can ſuggeſt.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may as well leave the letter, Bruſh—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir;—I thought as much—

sp.speaker: BEVERLEY
sp.p:
Now what varniſh will ſhe put upon the matter!— (reads)
The falſe gaiety of my heart, thro' which my dear Beverley might have read my real anguiſh at our laſt meeting, is now ſubſided. If you will come to me, I will not laugh at your inquietude of temper, but will clear all your doubts, and ſhew you how much I am, my deareſt Beverley, ever yours,
BELINDA BLANDFORD.
Pſhaw! ſatisfy my doubts—I have no doubts; I am convinced—theſe arts prevail no more—ha! ha! (laughs peeviſhly)—"my dear Beverley" (reads, and tears the letter by degrees)—"real anguiſh"—ha! ha! (tears another piece)—"inquietude of temper"— (another piece)—"clear all your doubts"—Po! po! po!—ha! ha!—damnation!—I'll think no more of her— (tears another bit)—ha! ha!—"deareſt Beverley"—ha! ha!—artful woman!—"ever yours"—falſe! falſe! falſe!— (tears another piece)—I'll not make myſelf uneaſy about her—Perfidy! treachery! and ingratitude!— (fixes his eye, looks uneaſy, and tears the letter all in ſcraps.)

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So, brother!—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Beverley!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Siſter, your ſervant—Mr. Bellmont, yours—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You ſeem melancholy, brother.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, not I—I am in very good ſpirits—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—my dear brother, that is ſeen thro', your ſoul is upon the rack.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What about a woman, a falſe, ungrateful woman!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Whom you ſtill admire—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: To whom you'll be upon your knees in five minutes.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You are miſtaken—I am going out of town—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But you will take your leave—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done that, once for all.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Has not ſhe wrote to you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She has; and there,—there you ſee the effect of her letter.—You will ſee I ſhall maintain a proper firmneſs on the occaſion—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Prithee no more, Beverley, but return to your duty—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I beg, Sir, you will have done—what, plead for treachery, for falſhood, for deceit—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: No, Sir, but for my friend, my lovely friend, for Belinda, for truth, for innocence—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! you don't know all the circumſtances—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: But we do know all the circumſtances, and, my dear brother, you have behaved very ill.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Heaven knows, I have not, and yet, heaven knows, I ſhould be glad to be convinced I have—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: I'll tell you what then, we women are ſoft and compaſſionate in our nature; go to her without delay, fall at her feet, beg her pardon, drop a tear or two, and all will be well again.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee don't laugh at me,—may contempt and beggary attend me,—may all the calamities of life befal me,—may ſhame, confuſion, and diſquiet of heart for ever ſting me,—if I hold farther intercourſe with her; if I do not put her from my thoughts for ever.—Did you leave her at home?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: We did.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, let her ſlay there—it is of no conſequence to me—how did ſhe bear what paſſed between us?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Like a ſweet girl as ſhe is; ſhe behaved like an angel; I ſhall love her better than ever for her good humour.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! I don't doubt her good humour—ſhe has ſmiles at command—let her ſmile or not ſmile, 'tis all alike to me—did ſhe ſay any thing?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She told us the whole ſtory, and told it in tears too.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ay! them ſhe can command too!—But I have no curioſity about her—was ſhe in tears tho'?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She was, and wept bitterly—how could you, brother, behave ſo raſhly to ſo amiable a girl?—have you a pleaſure in being the cauſe of her uneaſineſs?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I the cauſe!—you wrong me—by heaven you wrong me—my lady Reſtleſs was the cauſe—ſhe told me ſuch things—ſhe planted daggers in my very heart.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You planted daggers in her heart—and it was barbarous.—What, becauſe a lady has not ſtrength enough to bear up againſt a father, who is reſolved to give her away to another, and becauſe ſhe faints out of exceſſive tenderneſs for you, and in that diſtreſs meets accidental relief from Sir John Reſtleſs at his own door—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: How!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And becauſe my lady Reſtleſs ſees this out of her window, and has a perverſe talent of miſinterpreting appearances into realities, to her own diſadvantage—you muſt therefore fill your head with ungenerous ſuſpicions—Oh! for ſhame, for ſhame, how could you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But, is all this true?—is this really the caſe?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How can you doubt it, Beverley;—you know Belinda too well—it is the caſe, man.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to find it ſo—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p:
Well! well! I tell you it is ſo—how could you think otherwiſe, when you know ſhe has the beſt heart in the world, and is ſo nice of
honour, ſhe ſcorns all falſhood and diſſimulation—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! my dear Beverley, you have done the abſurdeſt thing—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Why, if what you ſay can be made to appear—but then ſhe'll never forgive my paſt behaviour—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Po! you talk as if you were wholly unletter'd in the tempers of women—my dear brother, you know, you men can do what you pleaſe with us, when you have got an intereſt in our hearts—go to her, I ſay, go to her, and make your peace—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: May I depend upon what you ſay?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Then I'll fly to her this inſtant, humble myſelf to her, and promiſe by all my future life to attone for this brutal injury—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: The chaiſe is at the door, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may put up again; I ſhan't go out of town.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—ha! ha!—you may put up, and let me have the chariot directly—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I knew it would come to this—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But do you think ſhe will forgive me?

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She will; love will plead your cauſe.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
My dear ſiſter, I am for ever obliged to you;—and Bellmont, I thank you too—how could I wrong her ſo?—I ſhall behold her once again—ha! ha!—is the chariot ready?—I won't ſtay for it; I am on the wing, my dear Belinda, to implore forgiveneſs—and ſo ſhe fainted away
in the Park, and my lady Reſtleſs ſaw Sir John afford her relief?—ha! ha! ha!—whimſical enough—ha! ha! ha!—what a ſtrange conſtruction her crazy temper put upon it?—ha! ha!—how could the woman be ſo fooliſh?—my dear Belinda, I will fly to you this moment—ha! ha!— (going, returns) Sir John ſhall give me back the picture, and, on my knees, I will once more preſent it—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So! ſo! ſo!—you are come to yourſelf, I find—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I knew it would be ſo—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She ſhall have it—I'll find Sir John directly—and then—ha! ha! how could I be ſuch a madman! ha! ha!—ſiſter, your ſervant—Bellmont, yours—ha! ha! what a piece of work has that fooliſh woman made for us all—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I am happy that I have nothing of my brother's unaccountable humours in my diſpoſition—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! my angel, you are all—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh lord! Oh lord!—no compliments, pray—I have not leiſure now to attend to you—for, poſitively, I muſt go back to Belinda, to ſee their reconciliation—will you go with me, Mr. Bellmont?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By all means—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Allons then; there, take my hand, and let us be gone.

This raſh, unaccountable man!—How could he entertain ſuch a ſuſpicion!—Ungrateſul Beverley!—He
almoſt deſerves I ſhould never ſee him again.—Tippet!—I ſhan't be eaſy till I hear from him—Tippet!—

sp.speaker: BELIND.
sp.p: Is the ſervant returned from Mr. Beverley's?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Not yet, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I wonder what keeps him.—I am upon thorns till I ſee the dear, ungenerous man, and explain every thing to him—Oh! Mr. Beverley! how could you treat me ſo?—But I was partly to blame; my lady Reſtleſs inflamed his mind, and I ſhould not have triſled with his paſſion—Is the other ſervant returned from Sir John Reſtleſs?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And what anſwer?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Sir John will wait upon you himſelf, madam, directly.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well!—I muſt get him to ſet every thing in its true light, and juſtify me to Mr. Beverley: and yet the uncertainty of his temper alarms me ſtrangely—his eternal ſuſpicions!—but there is nothing in that—my future conduct,—my regard for him will cure that diſeaſe, and then—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I dare be ſworn it will, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, I think it will; when he knows me better, he will learn to think generouſly of me—and on my part, I think I can be ſure he will meet with nothing but open, unſuſpecting love from me.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Sir John Reſtleſs, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Shew him in—Tippet, do you leave the room.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: In compliance with your commands, Madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I am much obliged to you for the trouble you have been pleaſed to give yourſelf—A particular circumſtance has happened in your family, to my utter diſquiet—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, there have happened things in my family, to my utter diſquiet too—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I am ſorry for that, Sir—but I aſſure you I have been made quite unhappy, and muſt beg, as it is in your power, that you will be kind enough to remove the cauſe of my uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Whatever I can do, you may command.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, and muſt tell you, that your lady has done me the moſt irreparable injury.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! ſhe has done the ſame to me—my injuries are irreparable too—but how has ſhe injured you, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: She has ruined me, Sir, with the man I love to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, here ſomething elſe will come to light, (aſide.)—How, how has ſhe done that, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, ſhe has entirely drawn off his affections from me.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And fixed them upon herſelf, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't ſay that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: But I dare ſay it; and I believe it.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, I don't charge the lady with any thing of that kind—but ſhe has unaccountably taken it into her head to be jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Jealous of you!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Her ladyſhip ſaw the little offices of civility I received from you this morning—She miſunderſtood every thing, it ſeems, and has told the gentleman with whom I was engaged in a treaty of marriage, that improper freedoms have paſſed between us.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Artifice! artifice!—her uſual policy, madam, to cover her own libertine ways.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't mean to ſay any thing harſh of the lady—but you know what foundation there is for this, and I hope will do me juſtice—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! madam, to the world, to the wide world I'll juſtify you—I will wait upon the gentleman—who is he, madam?—what's his name?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Beverley, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Beverley!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; you ſeem ſurpriſed—do you know him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know him—and he ſhall know me—my reſentment he ſhall feel—he ſhall anſwer to me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Anſwer to you!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: To me, madam—I told you at firſt this was her ſcheme to ſhelter herſelf; and he, I ſuppoſe, is combined with her to give this turn to the affair, and to charge me with infidelity—But you, ma'am, can witneſs for me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I can, Sir—But can Mr. Beverley be capable of a diſhonourable action?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! that matter is plain enough; he has injured me in the higheſt degree, deſtroyed my happineſs—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How, Sir!—are you ſure of this?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has giver her his picture; I caught her with her eyes rivetted to it; I heard her admiration, her praiſes of it; her wiſhes that ſhe had been married to ſuch a man—I ſaw her print a thouſand kiſſes on it; and in the very fact I wreſted it out of her hand—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Sir, if I imagined him to be ſuch as you deſcribe him, I ſhould ſcarcely be willing to join myſelf to him for life—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: As you pleaſe for that—but, without doubt, you muſt be very happy with a man of his gallantry.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Happy, Sir!—I ſhould be miſerable; I ſhould be diſtracted—I ſhould break my heart—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! it is very likely that he will have a great regard to the honour of the nuptial bed, he, who is ſo ready to commit a treſpaſs on his neighbour.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But do you think you have ſufficient proof?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I have ſeen him coming out of my houſe ſince, clandeſtinely, ſhunning every obſervant eye, with the characters of guilt in his face, and all the diſcourſe I had with him, ſerved only to convince me the more—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Abandoned wretch!—was this the love he profeſſed for me?—Sir, I have only to hope that you will vindicate me in this matter—I commend myſelf to your honour, and I thank you for this favour—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Our evidences will mutually ſpeak
for each other, and confound their dark deſigns—Madam, I take my leave—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt obedient—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You will find I ſhall make an example of the gentleman—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You cannot treat him too ſeverely—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will expoſe him, I promiſe you—Madam, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Beverley, could I have imagined this?—Falſe! falſe man!—and yet how ſhall I forget him!—But I will make an effort, tho' it pierce me to the quick—I will tear him from my heart—this moment I will write to him, and forbid him to ſee me more.

div.p: If I can procure ſufficient evidence, I ſhall bring the matter to a divorce, and make an example of them all—Would Marmalet were come—this is her time to a moment—If I can worm the ſecret out of her—then I am happy—Is not that ſhe yonder?—there is not quite day-light enough to diſtinguiſh, but I think I perceive a perſon maſked—hiſt! hiſt!—Mrs. Marmalet—ſhe comes this way—it is ſhe—Mrs. Marmalet, your ſervant—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very good, Mrs. Marmalet—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Bleſs my heart, I am ſeared out of my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter, pray?—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I tremble like a leaf—I was accoſted in a rude manner by ſome gentlemen yonder—Oh Lord! I can't ſtay here, let us go into your houſe, Sir—I beg you will.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My houſe—would not any other houſe do as well?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir—not for the world—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Why my wife is not at home, and ſo I think I may venture, not but I had rather it were elſewhere—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, I can't—you will do me a favour if you will take me into the houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Very well—ſay no more—it ſhall be ſo—Robert—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Is that Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your lady is not at home, Robert, is ſhe?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Then do you go in, and take care that nobody ſees Mrs. Marmalet with me—come, I'll ſhew you the way—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Ay, poor lady! ſhe is misfortunate, indeed—and, poor gentleman, he is as jealous as my lady to the full—There has been a deal to do about that picture you mention, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, all that will be explained preſently—I'll wait till he comes home—I can't poſſibly go without ſpeaking to him—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Indeed, you had better not ſtay, Sir—you don't conſider the miſchief your being in the houſe may occaſion—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Miſchief! how do ye mean?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Lord, Sir!—I would not have you ſtay for the world—I would not, indeed—you can call again in an hour, Sir, and you'll certainly find him at home, then—Bleſs my heart, Sir!—I fancy that's his voice—do, dear Sir!—you'll be the ruin of my lady—If he ſees you here, Sir, waiting in his houſe—he'll be perſuaded you come after my lady—the world will never beat it out of his head—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I ſhall give him to underſtand—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: He won't underſtand any thing, Oh lud! oh lud! he's coming up—I'll run and look.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What a flurry the woman is in—a fooliſh jade!—I muſt ſpeak with him now—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: (Entering.) It is he as I am alive, Sir—and there is a woman in a maſk with him—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A woman in a maſk—Zoons, if that ſhould be Belinda!—my mind miſgives me ſtrangely!—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Do, dear Sir—you look like a goodnatured gentleman—Let me hide you out of the way, Sir,—you would not be the deſtruction of a poor ſervant—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A maſk coming home with him—I muſt know who that is—I won't leave the houſe without knowing—If I could conceal myſelf—Have you any private place, Mrs. Tattle?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: That is the very thing I mean, Sir—Let me conceal you in that cloſet till he paſſes thro' this room—He never ſtays long here—it won't take you two minutes—Do, ſweet Sir—I'll down on my knees to you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
That will be the beſt way—Come, diſpoſe
of me as you will—If this ſhould be Belinda—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Heavens bleſs you, Sir, for this goodneſs!—I'll lock the door to make ſure work of it—Oh lud! Oh lud! I was never ſo frightened in my life—

div.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, and a Woman masked.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mrs. Marmalet, I am obliged to you for this favour—I wanted a word or two with you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: So Robert informed me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Did he tell you my buſineſs?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: No, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Look ye then, my dear Mrs. Marmalet, if you will gratify me in what I ſhall aſk, you may command any thing—now you may be uncovered—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: La! Sir—I hear a noiſe—I am afraid ſomebody's coming—and I ſhall be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Huſh! no—there's nobody—I'll tell you what—If you will indulge me on this occaſion, I am yours for ever—Here, here is a purſe of money for you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But if this ſhould come to the knowledge of your lady, I am ruined and undone—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, I'll take care of you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Will you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will—but come—let me remove this from your face—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But ſomebody may come—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll lock the door—there, now we are ſate—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But in a little time you'll make up all quarrels with your lady, and I ſhall get ruined by this—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, never fear—I ſhall never be reconciled to her—I hate her—deteſt her—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you ſo, Sir?—Now, Sir John, what can you ſay now, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My Lady Reſtleſs!—Confuſion!—What ſhall I ſay?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh, Sir John! Sir John!—what evaſion have you now, Sir?—Can you deny your guilt any longer?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is unlucky—that villain Robert has betrayed me—and I can't explain myſelf to her now—try what ſoothing will do—My Lady Reſtleſs—if you will but have patience all this matter ſhall be explained—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Explained, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, explained, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My dear, too!—the aſſurance of you!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I ſay, my dear, for I ſtill regard you—and this was all done—to—to—cure you of your jealouſy—all done to cure you of your jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: A fine way you have taken—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, yes—and ſo you will ſee preſently—all to convince you how groundleſs your ſuſpicions are; and then we ſhall live very happy together—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: For I have no further ſuſpicions of you—I ſee my error, and I want you to ſee yours—ha! ha!—I have no ſuſpicions—that will put her her off her guard— (aſide)—my dear, only compoſe your ſpirits, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And do you think to deny every thing even in the face of conviction—Baſe, baſe man!—I'll go this moment and write to my brother—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Po! po! you talk wildly—this is all raving—you make yourſelf very ridiculous—you do, indeed—I had ſettled all this on purpoſe, and contrived that it ſhould come to your ears, and then knew you would do juſt as you have done—and—then—I—I—reſolved to do juſt as I have dare—only to hint to you—that liſteners ſeldom hear any good of themſelves, and ſo ſhew you how wrong it is to be too ſuſpicious, my dear—and was it not well done?—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And do you laugh at me too, Sir?—make me your ſport?—I'll go and get pen and ink this moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! do ſo, ma'am—do ſo—ha! ha! you'll only expoſe yourſelf—go and write, madam—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I will, Sir—ha! the door is locked—this won't ſucceed, Sir—I ſuppoſe you have the key—ay! I'll lay my life you have, and ſome other of your creatures is locked in there—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There, again—this is of a piece with all your other ſuſpicions—ha! ha!—you are mighty ſilly, indeed, you are—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I will ſearch that cloſet—I am determined I will—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Do ſo, ma'am, do ſo—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I'll have the door broke open, if you don't give me the key—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Will you give me the key, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—Tattle!—who waits there?—I will find out all your artifices—Tattle, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Tol de rol lol—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of the key of that cloſet, Tattle?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: The key, ma'am!—I have it, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Give it to me—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: That is, I have it not, ma'am—oh! Crimini—what ſhall I do now?—don't have it, ma'am, don't aſk for it?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't aſk for it!—but I will have it, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! is not ſhe willing to give it?—there is ſomething in this, then—Give the key this moment, you jade, give it to me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You ſhan't have it, Sir—what, you want to hinder me!—give the key to me—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Lord! I have loſt it, ma'am—better not have it, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Give it to me this moment, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: If you don't let me have it, it is as much as your place is worth—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: The devil is in it—there it is then—let me make my eſcape.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Now, Sir, we ſhall ſee—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, now ſearch, if you will—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You ſhall be found out, I promiſe you—oh! (ſcreams out)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Heavens! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh there is ſomebody there then!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam—your moſt obedient—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: By all that's falſe, here he is again!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What, in the name of wonder, brings you here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh madam! you know his buſineſs—and I know his buſineſs—and the gentleman knows his buſineſs—There he is, ma'am!—there is the gentleman waiting for you—true to his appointment, you ſee—Sir, your humble ſervant—my lady Reſtleſs, your very humble ſervant, madam.—Now write to your brother—do—I ſhould be glad to know what you can ſay now—now—now—is the caſe plain now?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I am in amaze! I don't know what to make of this.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, however odd this may appear—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! now ſettle it between yourſelves—give it what turn you will, Sir, ſhe will confirm it,—you need not be afraid, Sir—you will agree in your ſtory—ſhe is quick of invention, I aſſure you,—and I dare ſay you are pretty quick too!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt beg you will put no forced conſtruction upon this matter—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And you beg the ſame, ma'am, don't you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I beg to be heard—my buſineſs here, Sir, is to deſire you will return me that picture you have in your poſſeſſion!—it is now become dear to me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I dare ſay it is—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And I muſt have it back.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, it is of equal value to me, and it ſhall riſe in evidence againſt you both.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Evidence againſt me!—pray Sir, I deſire you will explain yourſelf.—How did you get in here?—what's your buſineſs?—what brought you hither?—what's your errand?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſpeak; how did you get in here?—what's your buſineſs?—what brought you hither?—what's your errand?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Zoons! I am beſet by them both at once—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Speak, Sir,—explain—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! Sir, explain—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, if you will give me leave, I will ſatisfy you entirely—I aſſure you, Sir, and you too, ma'am, that my being in your cloſet is entirely owing to your maid, Tattle—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The jade, I don't doubt it, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: To prevent, if poſſible, the interpretation you now put upon ſeeing me in your houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And it was well contrived, Sir—Oh! my lady Reſtleſs—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: By all that's juſt, I knew nothing of it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Nothing, upon my honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! I knew you would both agree—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman, I tell you the real fact.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You need not, Sir, I know the real fact.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I have no time to loſe, and I muſt now deſire the picture, directly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh you a good evening.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I can't ſtir without it; and I ſhould be glad you would comply without a quarrel, or really I muſt be obliged to—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! now her bully begins! (aſide.)—I deſire you will quit my houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am not to be treated in this manner, Sir, and, if you don't return it by fair means, I ſhall be forced to draw, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There again now!—ſhe has ſet him on to cut my throat—but I will diſappoint her—ſhe is a worthleſs woman, and I won't fight about her.—There, Sir, there is your trinket—I ſhall have proof ſufficient without it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Upon my honour, Sir, you will have no proof of any miſbehaviour of mine, and, if you ſuſpect your lady from theſe appearances, you wrong her much, I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire you will explain all this—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Call up your maid, madam, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Sir, no more of it—I am ſatisfied—I wiſh you good night, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, when you are willing to liſten to reaſon, I ſhall at any time convince you how wrong you are, and madam, you may depend I ſhall do juſtice to your honour upon all occaſions—and I take my leave—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, my lady Reſtleſs, now you ſee you are thoroughly known; all your artifices are known—Mr. Beverley is known! my lord Conqueſt is known—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My lord Conqueſt, Sir! I deſpiſe all your imputations—my lord Conqueſt's maid, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Very well, madam! 'tis now my turn to write to your brother, and I promiſe you I will do it—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You will write, Sir!—you will write!—I will recollect my temper—his aſſurance is unequalled (aſide.)—Oh! do ſo, Sir,—do ſo—ha! ha! but you will only expoſe your weakneſs—ha! ha! you make yourſelf very ridiculous! you do indeed!—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! madam, am I to be inſulted with a contumelious laugh into the bargain!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Why, my dear, this was all done—to—to—to—cure you of your jealouſy—for I knew you would do as you have done, and ſo I—reſolved to do as I have done—was it not well done, my dear, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Damnation, madam!—this is beyond all human patience—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! la lall lall lall, (ſings and laughs)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me tell you, it is no laughing matter—you are a vile woman; I know you, and the world ſhall know you—I promiſe you it ſhall—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I am clear in my own conviction, and your ſlander I deſpiſe—nor ſhall your artifice blind me or my friends any longer—Sir, as you ſay it is no laughing matter—and I promiſe you, Sir—you ſhall never diſhonour me again in this houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And I promiſe you, madam, that you ſhall never diſhonour me in any houſe.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Injurious, falſe, falſe man!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deceitful—wanton—wanton woman!—

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter old BLANDFORD, Sir WILLIAM, and young BELLMONT.

sp.speaker: BLANDFORD.
sp.p: WELL, Sir William, we have made a good day's work of it, the writings will be ready to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: The ſooner the better, is your daughter Belinda at home?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I dare ſay ſhe is—I ordered her home in the morning, I make no doubt but ſhe has been at home ever ſince—I'll call her to you—excuſe me a moment, Sir William,—young gentleman, I beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No ceremony, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you was coming hither, George, to wait upon your miſtreſs, when I met you but now—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir—you may depend—every thing in my power to pleaſe you, Sir—but you know I told you already, Sir, that the lady has declared an averſion for me.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p:
An averſion!—a fiddle for her averſion—has not her father promiſed her to you in
marriage?—and ſo, what have you to do with her averſion?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To do with it, Sir!—egad, I am afraid I ſhall have a great deal to do with it,—you know, when a young lady marries againſt her inclination, billets-doux, aſſignations, plots, and intrigues, and a terrible et caetera of female ſtratagems, mount into her brain, and—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Come, come, lad, don't play the rogue with your father—did not you promiſe me, if Belinda conſented, the affair would meet with no obſtacle from you?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I did, Sir,—but I can't help thinking—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And I can't help thinking that you are a knave, George.—I'll tell you what, I have fixed my heart upon this marriage—my friend Mr. Blandford and I have been dining upon parchment, as I may ſay; we have been at the Crown and Rolls all day, to read over the deeds—and ſo I tell you, once for all, you muſt be obſervant of my will and pleaſure.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, if Belinda—ſhe will never conſent (aſide.)—If the lady, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Very well, ſhe will be conſenting—I warrant her—now we ſhall ſee—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Ods heart! I am overjoyed, Sir William—my daughter is a complying, good girl, and obedient to her father—young gentleman, I give you joy.—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Death to my hopes! what does he mean?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, give me your hand upon it—this will not only be a match of prudence, but inclination alſo—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: There, George, there's news for you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sure ſhe won't bring this calamity on me—Can I believe what I hear, madam?—will you yourſelf pronounce the ſentence?—

sp.speaker: BELin.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt take ſhame to myſelf, that I have been ſo long refractory to the dictates of the beſt of fathers, and blind alſo to your merit.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Confuſion! (aſide)—My merit, I am afraid, is over-rated by you, and—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir;—I muſt freely declare that my heart has been fixed upon a worthleſs man, whom I now renounce, and to you, Sir, I am ready to reſign myſelf.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: There, there, all's fixed, and my bleſſing attend you both.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a dilemma am I brought into here?

sp.speaker: Sir WIL
sp.p: George, what's the matter, boy?—you a bridegroom!—wounds! at your age I would cut a caper over the moon on ſuch an occaſion.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt beg to be excuſed—I am a little more ſlack-mettled, Sir, and can't leap quite ſo high.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Well, well, all in good time—Mr. Blandford, where is this bottle you promiſed me?—I want to waſh down the cobwebs of the law—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: In truth ſo do I—Who waits there?—Richard, lay a table in the next room—come, come, we'll go and drink a bumper to the young couple.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: With all my heart—George, you are a cup too low; come with us my lad, we'll cheer your ſpirits—come along, George (going.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I attend you, Sir—is this true, Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My real ſentiments, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then you have undone us all.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Yes, I am reſolved at length, and I will puniſh his falſehood and ingratitude by obeying my father's commands. But my friend, Clariſſa, has ſhe deſerved this of me?—My reſentments have hurried me too far—Reſume your ſtrength, my heart, and let no ſudden guſt of paſſion make you falſe to friendſhip and to honour—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Tippet, have you done as I ordered you?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: A vile, perſidious man!

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: So he is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: After all the love I profeſſed for him!—after ſo many ardent vows and proteſtations as he has made me—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: After the hours he has kneel'd at your feet!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I will drive him from my thoughts—here, take this letter, Tippet—give it to him with your own hands.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Where are his letters?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Here, madam. (ſhews a parcel)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: The bracelet—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have it ſafe.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mighty well—take them all home to him,—and, in return, bring me back my fooliſh letters to him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, I won't quit the houſe without them.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: That letter will inform him that his Falſehood has compelled me into a compliance with my father's intentions, and be ſure you confirm that to him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He ſhall hear it of every ſide of his ears, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well, you may go—and, hark ye, Tippet—aſk his man,—as if from yourſelf,—careleſly,—whether his maſter ever talked of me—and what he ſaid, Tippet?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But I don't care what he ſaid—I don't want to know any thing about him—it does not concern me now—no—no—let him care as little for me as I do for him—Tell him I ſay ſo—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I ſhan't forget, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Tell him to hate me as much as I do him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I'll tell him his own—I promiſe you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well—that's all;—get you gone—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mind what I have ſaid—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Truſt to me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Don't forget a tittle—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: No, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Be ſure you tell him how indifferent I am—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Leave all to me.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You ſee, Tippet, I am quite unconcerned—the barbarous wretch!

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Oh! yes, ma'am, I ſee—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: It is eaſy to ſee that I am not all uneaſy—You ſee that I am very gay upon it— (laughs affectedly.)

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: (Laughs) Yes, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Falſe! falſe Beverley!—Tell him I will never ſee his face any more.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I am gone, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: That upon no account will I ever exchange a word with him, hear from him, of him, or have any thing of any kind whatever to do with him—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have my leſſon, ma'am.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley, madam.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: My lady won't ſee his face any more.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, I think, I will—ſhew him in—I will ſee him once more, and tell him all myſelf—You may withdraw, Tippet.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—ah! ſhe has a hankerafter him ſtill.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Now will I upbraid him, now tell him his own, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—how gladly do I once again behold—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And with what reſentment have not I reaſon to behold, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You have, Belinda;—you have reaſon, I grant it—but—forgive the raſh words my folly uttered—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, miſtake me not—they are not your words I quarrel with;—your actions, Mr. Beverley, your actions, Sir!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: They are not to be extenuated—but ſurely, after the letter you honoured me with—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard every thing ſince I was guilty of that folly.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Heard! what?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, diſſemble if you will—but this muſt be the laſt of our converſing—My maid will return you whatever I have received from you;—and all my ſilly letters I muſt beg you will let me have,—and then viſit me no more, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—you will not wound me thus—Here is the picture which cauſed that unlucky miſtake between us—I have recovered it from Sir John Reſtleſs—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: From my Lady Reſtleſs, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! fie, Sir—no more—I have done—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You muſt, you muſt accept it—Thus on my knees I beg you will—Will you, Belinda?—(takes her hand.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Leave me, Sir—let go my hand, Mr. Beverley—your falſhood, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My falſhood!—by all the—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Your falſhood, Sir—Sir John Reſtleſs has told me all—every circumſtance—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: He has told you!—What has he told? his life ſhall anſwer it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How could you treat me thus?—you have deſtroyed my peace of mind for ever—Nay, you yourſelf have forced me into the arms of another—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What do I hear?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: In obedience to the commands of a father, I have agreed to marry Mr. Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Mr. Bellmont!—him!—marry him!—it is very well, ma'am,—I expected it would come to this—and my Lady Reſtleſs is only mentioned on this occaſion, as a retort for my accuſation about Sir John—I underſtand it—and, by heaven! I believe that whole ſtory—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You do, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I do—Fool that I was to humble myſelf to you—My pride is now piqued, and I am glad, ma'am—as glad as you can be to break off for ever—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I can be as indifferent on my part—Then, Sir, you have only to ſend me back my letters, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! agreed, agreed—I'll go home this moment, and ſend them all—and before I go, ma'am, here is your own picture, which you had given me with your own hands.—Mr. Bellmont will be glad of it—or Sir John Reſtleſs will be glad of it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very like, Sir,—(takes the picture) Tyrant, tyrant man! to treat me in this barbarous manner—(cries.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Tears! Belinda! (approaching)—Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: No more of your inſidious arts—I will hear no more—Oh! my heart,—my heart will break—I did not think it was in your nature to behave as you have done; but—farewel for ever—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Belinda!—hear me but ſpeak—By heaven, my Lady Reſtleſs—She is gone—'sdeath! I have been duped by her all this time; I
will now ſummon up all that is man within me, and in my turn deſpiſe her.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: If you are going home, Sir, I will take the things with me now—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, I am going—I will leave this deteſted—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: This abominable place, Sir— (laughing at him.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This hell!—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—ay! Sir, this hell—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This manſion of perfidy, ingratitude, and fraud—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Very right, Sir, let us go—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And yet—Tippet,—you muſt not ſtir—indulge me but a little—it is all a miſunderſtanding, this—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: My lady will have no more to ſay to theſe things—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Tippet, uſe your intereſt with her—keep them in the houſe till I return—I will clear up this whole matter preſently—I muſt not loſe her thus—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Poor gentleman! he ſeems in a lamentable way—Well, I fancy for my part he is a true lover after all; that's what I do—and my young lady, I fear, is—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, madam, madam, you are to blame—you are, indeed—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Did he ſay any thing? was he uneaſy?—or did he carry it off with a—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, he went away ſighing ſhort, his heart throbbing, his eyes brimful, his looks pale—you are to blame, you are, indeed, madam—I dare be ſworn he has never proved falſe.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Tippet, could I be ſure of that—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: But you are not ſure of the contrary—Why won't you ſee my Lady Reſtleſs?—ſee her directly, madam; go to her now before it is too late;—before the old folks, who are now putting their heads together, have ſettled the whole affair—do, dear ma'am, be adviſed—ſhall I order your chair?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay—I am afraid I love him ſtill—yes, I will ſee my Lady Reſtleſs—I will be thoroughly informed of the whole matter—order my chair—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am; I will, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If I ſhould loſe him thro' a miſapprehenſion of things, I ſhall never be able to forgive myſelf; and if rightly informed, the world combined ſhall not induce me to look upon him again.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Belinda, you have puzzled matters ſtrangely; you have involved your friend Clariſſa, yourſelf, me, and every body, in the moſt inſurmountable difficulties—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, the provocation I have had from Mr. Beverley—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
You wrong him, I am perſuaded you do; and ſo you will find in the end—But what
can be done now?—the old people are fixed in their reſolution, and fixed by your own raſhneſs.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What can I ſay, Mr. Bellmont?—the agitation of my mind is ſuch, between hope and doubt, and fear and reſentment, that I know not which way to turn myſelf. If Beverley is falſe,—if he is true,—I am equally undone.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So, Mr. Bellmont! (angrily.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! Clariſſa, there have been ſuch doings between your brother and me—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So I find, ma'am—I met him as I came hither—You have had fine doings, indeed—I have heard it all—and you can be falſe to your promiſes, ma'am, falſe to your friends—and you too, Mr. Bellmont, you can be falſe to all your engagements, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Do me not that injuſtice, Clariſſa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, don't imagine I am angry with you, or with you, madam—you will be well paired—I give ye both joy—I am heartily glad, Sir, that I at length know you,—I reſign him to you, ma'am,—I aſſure you I do—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Give me but a moment's leave—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word, Clariſſa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And upon my word, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Nay, but moderate your anger—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Anger! anger, indeed!—I ſhould be ſorry any thing that has happened were of conſequence enough to diſturb my peace of mind—Anger!—no, ma'am, I aſſure you—Mr. Bellmont, I dare ſay, will be fully deſerving of you; and you, madam, on your part, will very amply deſerve ſuch a huſband—Anger, indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If you will but hear me a moment—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My dear Clariſſa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! my dear ma'am, you are a ſincere friend I know, ma'am (with a ſneer) but, my dear ma'am, don't ſtand on ceremony—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Whatever has paſſed, Clariſſa, I am not to blame—I have ever been—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You have been falſe, Sir—but you have my conſent, I promiſe you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But you won't hear me,—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: No, ſhe won't liſten to a word—I mean you no wrong, Clariſſa—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, the chair is ready—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well!—I won't loſe a moment now—Clariſſa, when I return, you will be better diſpoſed to hear me.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, there is no occaſion.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well! well!—ſuſpend your judgment till I come back; your ſervant—adieu.—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! your ſervant, ma'am—Mr. Bellmont, my brother, I promiſe you, will never forgive this injury—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If you will have but a moment's patience—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! I ſhan't want patience,—don't imagine that—I ſhall be very patient, I promiſe you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Nay, but this is very ill-tempered—one would imagine my lady Reſtleſs had been ſpeaking to you too—this is like the reſt of them;—downright jealouſy—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Jealouſy!—upon my word, Sir, you are of great conſequence to yourſelf, but of none to me I aſſure you, Sir,—jealouſy! I ſhall die with laughing at the thought—but, before I go, I will write a line to Belinda—to tell her all I know and think of her—Mrs. Tippet will let me have pen, ink, and paper, above ſtairs—and as to you, Sir—I have told you my mind already—Jealouſy!—I can't help being diverted with the very notion of it—your moſt obedient, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a deal of miſchief has a ſtrange miſunderſtanding of circumſtances occaſioned this day!—here comes my father—now to perplex matters if I can—and ſo gain at leaſt a little delay—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Well, George! every thing is ſettled—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But ſtill, Sir, I wiſh you would conſider—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: What, at your tricks again, lad?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You know, Sir, I am above even an attempt to deceive you—but only reflect, Sir,—this is but a forced conſent from the lady—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: What, going back from your word, George?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Sir; but I am ſure, if all circumſtances were known to you, you yourſelf would forbid the banns.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: How! how!—what's the matter, George?—I forbid the banns! for what?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, I am not fond of ſpeaking detractingly of a young lady; but, for the honour
of your family, Sir, let us deſiſt from this match; that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Roguery, lad!—there's roguery in this.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ſee you will force me to ſpeak out—there is a flaw in her reputation, Sir; ſhe is blemiſhed—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Blemiſhed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, blemiſhed; my lady Reſtleſs, a very agreeable, worthy lady here in the neighbourhood, has diſcovered an illicit commerce between her and Sir John—the whole charge is come to Beverley's knowledge, and, with tears in his eyes, with a bleeding heart, for he loved her tenderly, he has made his bow to her charms, and taken his final leave.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Ay! lad—is this true?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Too true, I aſſure you, Sir—my lady will confirm it;—and ſo now judge whether—Oh! here comes Mr. Blandford—take no notice to him, Sir;—we need not be acceſſary to her ruin; it is a family affair, and ſo let them patch it up among themſelves, as well as they can—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: If things be as you ſay, George—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Supper will be ready immediately, Sir William—odds heart!—my ſpirits are above proof with joy, that this matter is ſo happily ſettled; I am in love with my daughter for her compliance, and I fancy I ſhall throw in an odd thouſand more, to be ſpent in the honey-moon—Where is Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I really can't ſay, Sir; ſhe is not at home.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Not at home!—What can be the meaning of that? where could ſhe go at this hour of night?—I am alarmed—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: She is not gone after this Beverley, I hope!—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: If ſhe is—Tippet!—who anſwers there?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Where is Belinda?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Gone in a chair to Sir John Reſtleſs—not far off, Sir; juſt bye here—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Gone to Sir John Reſtleſs!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir!—(to Sir William.)

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I did not think ſhe had been acquainted there—ſhe has got ſome freak in her head, I fear.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Why, it has an odd appearance this—let us follow her thither—this ſhould be enquired into.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Ay! let us loſe no time—let us follow her immediately; come along—

sp.speaker: Sir. WIL.
sp.p: I attend you, Sir—come along, George—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I will but get my hat, in the next room, Sir, and follow you directly.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Very well! now I ſhall ſee whether you have impoſed upon your father—

And now, Clariſſa, now will I explain to you all my ſufferings; the very ſentiments of my
heart—if my lady Reſtleſs perſiſts in her accuſation, who knows what turn this affair may ſtill take—I will but ſpeak to Clariſſa, and follow them inſtantly.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at Sir JOHN's.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: This way, Sir, I will let Sir John know.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſhan't detain him long, you may ſay.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I thought I heard Sir John talking with my maid.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The buſineſs is preſſing, or I ſhould not trouble him at this hour.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Did not I hear a man in diſcourſe with my wife!—ſo—ſo—ſo—he has got into my houſe again!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! only ſay that my buſineſs is very urgent, that's all—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I dare ſay it is—and there ſhe comes to you.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Well, Sir, have you heard any thing farther?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir John has been with Belinda ſince I had the pleaſure of ſeeing you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I make no doubt of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And I am informed, that he has taken it into his head to ſuſpect me, madam, which is ſo very unjuſt, that—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Entering) Yes, Sir, I do ſuſpect you,—and, Sir, this frequent haunting of my houſe—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir John Reſtleſs, you have injured me in my love, in my honour, Sir, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, you have injured me in my love and in my honour, Sir—no—not my love, for that is over—I deſpiſe her, ſcorn her, reject her—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: That is ever the way with thoſe who have deſerved contempt themſelves, Sir John.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt beg to diſcuſs this affair with ſome temperance, for it is of moment to me, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Running to meet her) There, madam, there you find them both together,— (Pointing at Beverley and lady Reſtleſs.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Now, Sir; you ſee ſhe comes to my very houſe after him, (pointing at Sir John and Belinda.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, madam, judge for yourſelf, (to Belinda.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Does this convince you, Sir, (to Beverley)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley! Both ſtaring at each other.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda! Both ſtaring at each other.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: By heaven! I fear my information is right.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Did you find them together, Sir, (to Sir John.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Found them together, madam!—

sp.speaker: BEL
sp.p: Then I am ſatisfied— Each ſpeaking apart.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! the baſe man! Each ſpeaking apart.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Abandoned woman! Each ſpeaking apart.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Treacherous Belinda! Each ſpeaking apart.

div.stage: Enter Mr. BLANDFORD, and Sir WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir John Reſtleſs,—my lady Reſtleſs,—I apprehend you are the gentleman, Sir,—and you the lady, ma'am—I came hither in queſt of my daughter—ſo, Belinda!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Are you her father?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I am, madam,—Mr. Beverley here too!—I ſee how this is, Belinda—you have eloped from your father, have you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Eloped! mind that Sir John,—the thing is clear.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: So I think it is—and I ſhould be glad to know which of you encourages her to take this ſtep.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: All Sir John's doings, Sir.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir John, I muſt tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, let me aſſure you firſt, there is no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Heavens deliver me!—how can you ſay ſo?—Sir, (to Blandford) I am very ſorry to ſay any thing diſagreeable to a father of his daughter—but, when my happineſs is deſtroyed, ceremony is unneceſſary,—your daughter has made me miſerable, Sir.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: What? how?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John Reſtleſs and ſhe, Sir—I cannot ſpeak, (cries.)

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Belinda! you will make your father wretched—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I make you wretched, Sir!—there is no action of my life—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Sir John Reſtleſs—this is my ſon, Sir—he is intereſted in this matter.—George, things turn out as you told me,— (aſide to him.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mr. Blandford, you are father to this lady, Sir—don't make yourſelf uneaſy; for I will vouch for her innocence of my lady's charge againſt her.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: He will deny every thing, no doubt—but facts are too ſtubborn, and ocular demonſtration I have had.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Ocular demonſtration!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I have ſeen their familiarities.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: George, take Clariſſa as ſoon as you will—Mr. Blandford, you will excuſe me, if I decline any further treaty with you—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Stay but a little till we hear the whole—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire to hear no more—I am ſatisfied, and muſt deſire not to marry my ſon into your family—Clariſſa—you have my conſent as ſoon as you pleaſe—my ſon is at your ſervice—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p:
Then, Sir William, ſince you provoke me, Sir, you ſhan't have my daughter.
—Mr. Beverley, I no longer oppoſe your inclinations, ſhe is yours—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Do you ſlight my ſon, Sir?—you uſe me very ill—and I would have you know—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: You ſhall never refuſe my daughter again, I promiſe you—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Nor ſhall you my ſon, Sir—Here, George, take your Clariſſa—I give her away to you—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: The gentleman has declared himſelf for that lady, and—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, ma'am, that lady has no ſhare in my affections, and, in compliance with my father's injunctions, thus let me ſeize your hand, and devote to you all my future days.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: It's very well, Sir William,—Mr. Beverley, here is my daughter for you—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay, now, if he will accept of her, I ſhall begin to think that I have been miſtaken—and that all my ſuſpicions of the lady are without foundation—But, I dare ſay, the gentleman knows better—What do you ſay, Sir? will you marry the lady?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: If that proof will ſatisfy you, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Hold, hold, a moment—Explain the buſineſs that brought you hither, Sir; anſwer to Sir John's charge againſt you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN
sp.p: Ay, Sir, anſwer that—if ſhe agrees to marry him, I ſhall be ſatisfied too—But, Sir, my lady's being in poſſeſſion of your picture, your frequent viſits to my houſe, Sir, and other circumſtances—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, a word or two will clear that matter—I had given a picture to this lady in the Park—ſhe, I find, dropped it when ſhe fainted away—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Did you faint, Belinda?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I did, Sir, immediately after you treated me in ſuch ſevere terms—in the morning—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And then it was I accidentally came to her relief, which my lady, according to cuſtom, has conceived in the manner you ſee.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: And how came you by the picture, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I found it in the very ſpot where I ſaw your daughter in the Park. The truth begins to break in upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This opens my eyes a little—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: And have you been ingenious enough, madam, to work up all theſe circumſtances into a charge againſt Sir John—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: 'I is ever her way, Sir—I told you how ridiculous you would make yourſelf, my dear; ha! ha!—You ſee, what your ſuſpicions are come to at laſt—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And you may ſee, Sir John, what your ſuſpicions are come to—I never was within your doors before this day; nor ſhould I perhaps have ſpoke to my lady, had it not been for the miſtakes your mutual jealouſies occaſioned between Belinda and me—I cannot help laughing at the whole affair—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, you may laugh—but I have another complaint againſt my Lady Reſtleſs—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John, Sir John, I have another charge againſt you—that jade whom you made an aſſignation with—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! madam, Robert knows that whole affair—I'll bring him hither directly, and
convict you before the whole company—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Artful, cunning man! you ſhan't ſpeak to him apart;—you ſhan't ſuborn witneſſes—I'll purſue you—gentlemen, let me intreat you to ſtep this way—you will be of great ſervice.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: If we can be of any, madam—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Faith, I believe all this puzzle has aroſe from their jealouſy; let us ſee the end of it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now, Beverley, now Belinda, make good uſe of your time, and all will be well ſtill.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I ſee, I ſee my raſhneſs—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I have been deceived, I find

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: If ſhe would but forgive my folly—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why does he not ſpeak to me?—I can't ſpeak firſt—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley!— (ſmiles aſide.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't you think you have been cruel to me, Belinda?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Don't you think you have behaved worſe to me, Mr. Beverley?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have; I grant it; Oh! Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Without looking at him.) You firſt diſordered my whole frame of mind, and can you wonder—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! my ſoul, my life, it was all my fault.— (Throws his arm round her waiſt) do you forgive me?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Leaning on his ſhoulder) You knew the generoſity of my temper, the ſincerity of my affection, how could you let an extravagance of temper ſo far get the better—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I bluſh for it—do you forgive me?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Drawing cloſer to him, and ſmiling)—No—I hate you!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (Kiſſing her cheek) Do you hate me, Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Was it not unkind?—Was it not ungenerous?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It was—thus on my knees—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! proud man, have I humbled you once more?—Well, now you are on your knees, I forgive you—Beg my picture back of me this moment—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (Taking it) Oh! I will adore it ever, and heal this breach with uninterrupted love—

div.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, Lady RESTLESS, Sir WILLIAM, Mr. BLANDFORD, BELLMONT, and CLARISSA.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—yes, faith, I ſee we have both made ourſelves very ridiculous.—Ha! ha—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I ſee and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Egad! I own it;—I can laugh at my own folly and my wife's too—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Why yes, Sir John, you have been both terribly in the wrong, indeed;—but, Belinda, don't you be in the wrong too—accept of Mr. Beverley this moment.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If you inſiſt upon it—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I do inſiſt upon it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Thus let me take the bright reward of all my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and now it's over; you have but commanded me to gratify my inclinations, for we have both ſeen our error, and frankly confeſs we have been in the wrong too.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Faith, I think we have been all ſo; Mr. Blandford, we ſhould not have oppoſed their inclinations, when we had it in our power to make two ſuch happy matches inſtead of one—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Very true; and now I wiſh the young folks all happineſs;—and, Sir John, I wiſh you and your lady happy too—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, it has been a day of miſtakes, but of fortunate ones, I hope, and may tend to all our advantage—My lady here will be taught—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John, I hope you will be taught—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Never mention what is paſt—the wrangling of married people about any little miſconduct is only like the laſhing of a top; it ſerves to keep it up the longer.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very right, Sir; and as we have been all in the wrong this day, we will, for the future, endeavour to be "All in the Right."

div.stage: Here Lady Reſtleſs talks apart with Belinda.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A good propoſal, Sir John; we will make it our buſineſs, both you who are married, and we who are entering into that ſtate, by mutual confidence, to inſure mutual happineſs.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
A match, Mr. Beverley; I ſubſcribe to it;—
The god of love thinks we prophane his fire,
When trifles light as air miſtruſt inſpire.
But where eſteem and gen'rous paſſions ſpring,
There reigns ſecure, and waves his purple wing;
Gives home-felt peace, prevents the nuptial ſtrife,
Endears the bliſs, and bids it laſt for life.
